        <a href="/wiki/ChEMBL" title="ChEMBL">
         ChEMBL
        </a>
       </th>
       <td>
        <span class="reflink plainlinks nourlexpansion">
         <a class="external text" href="https://www.ebi.ac.uk/chembldb/index.php/compound/inspect/CHEMBL263881" rel="nofollow">
          CHEMBL263881
         </a>
        </span>
        <sup>
         <img alt="Yes" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="600" height="7" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/fb/Yes_check.svg/7px-Yes_check.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/fb/Yes_check.svg/11px-Yes_check.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/fb/Yes_check.svg/14px-Yes_check.svg.png 2x" width="7"/>
         <span style="display:none">
          Y
         </span>
        </sup>
       </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
       <th scope="row" style="padding:0.1em 0;line-height:1.2em;">
        <a href="/wiki/Synonym" title="Synonym">
         Synonyms
        </a>
       </th>
       <td>
        Acid, LSD, lysergide
       </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
       <th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;background:#ddd">
        Chemical data
       </th>
      </tr>
      <tr>
       <th scope="row" style="padding:0.1em 0; line-height:1.2em;--&gt;">
        <a href="/wiki/Chemical_formula" title="Chemical formula">
         Formula
        </a>
       </th>
       <td>
        <a href="/wiki/Carbon" title="Carbon">
         <span style="color: rgb(000,000,000); font-weight: bold;">
          C
         </span>
        </a>
        <sub>
         20
        </sub>
        <a href="/wiki/Hydrogen" title="Hydrogen">
         <span style="color: rgb(77,77,77); font-weight: bold;">
          H
         </span>
        </a>
        <sub>
         25
        </sub>
        <a href="/wiki/Nitrogen" title="Nitrogen">
         <span style="color: rgb(0,0,128); font-weight: bold;">

         3
        </sub>

         <span style="color: rgb(116,35,35); font-weight: bold;">

        </a>
       </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
       <th scope="row" style="padding:0.1em 0; line-height:1.2em;--&gt;">
        <a href="/wiki/Molecular_mass" title="Molecular mass">
         Molecular mass
        </a>
       </th>
       <td>
        323.44gmol
        <sup>
         1
        </sup>
       </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
       <td colspan="2" style="text-align:center">
        <div class="NavFrame collapsed" style="border: none; padding: 0;">
         <div class="NavHead" style="font-size: 105%; background: transparent; text-align: left;">
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Simplified_molecular_input_line_entry_specification" title="Simplified molecular input line entry specification">
           SMILES
          </a>
         </div>
         <ul class="NavContent" style="list-style: none none; margin-left: 0; word-break:break-all; text-align:left; padding-left:1.5em; font-size: 105%; margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0; line-height: inherit;">
          <li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0">
           <div style="word-wrap:break-word; text-indent:-1.5em">
            CCN(CC)C(=O)[C@H]1CN([C@@H]2Cc3c[nH]c4c3c(ccc4)C2=C1)C
           </div>
          </li>
         </ul>
        </div>
       </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
       <td colspan="2" style="text-align:center">
        <div class="NavFrame collapsed" style="border: none; padding: 0;">
         <div class="NavHead" style="font-size: 105%; background: transparent; text-align: left;">
          <a href="/wiki/International_Chemical_Identifier" title="International Chemical Identifier">
           InChI
          </a>
         </div>
         <ul class="NavContent" style="list-style: none none; margin-left: 0; word-break:break-all; text-align:left; padding-left:1.5em; font-size: 105%; margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0; line-height: inherit;">
          <li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0">
           <div style="word-wrap:break-word; text-indent:-1.5em">
            InChI=1S/C20H25N3O/c1-4-23(5-2)20(24)14-9-16-15-7-6-8-17-19(15)13(11-21-17)10-18(16)22(3)12-14/h6-9,11,14,18,21H,4-5,10,12H2,1-3H3/t14-,18-/m1/s1
            <sup>
             <img alt="Yes" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="600" height="7" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/fb/Yes_check.svg/7px-Yes_check.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/fb/Yes_check.svg/11px-Yes_check.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/fb/Yes_check.svg/14px-Yes_check.svg.png 2x" width="7"/>

              Y

            </sup>
           </div>

            <sup>
             <img alt="Yes" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="600" height="7" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/fb/Yes_check.svg/7px-Yes_check.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/fb/Yes_check.svg/11px-Yes_check.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/fb/Yes_check.svg/14px-Yes_check.svg.png 2x" width="7"/>

       </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
       <th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;background:#ddd">
        Physical data
       </th>
      </tr>
      <tr>
       <th scope="row" style="padding:0.1em 0;line-height:1.2em;">
        <a href="/wiki/Melting_point" title="Melting point">
         Melting point
        </a>
       </th>
       <td>
        80 to 85C (176 to 185F)
       </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
       <th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;background:#ddd">
        <img alt="Yes" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="600" height="14" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/fb/Yes_check.svg/14px-Yes_check.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/fb/Yes_check.svg/21px-Yes_check.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/fb/Yes_check.svg/28px-Yes_check.svg.png 2x" width="14"/>
        <span style="display:none">
         Y
        </span>
        <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:WikiProject_Chemicals/Chembox_validation" title="Wikipedia:WikiProject Chemicals/Chembox validation">
         (what is this?)
        </a>
        <span class="reflink plainlinks nourlexpansion">
         <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Special:ComparePages&amp;rev1=629704081&amp;page2=Lysergic+acid+diethylamide">
          (verify)
         </a>
        </span>
       </th>
      </tr>
     </table>
     <p>
      <b>
       Lysergic acid diethylamide
      </b>
      (
      <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
       /da el mad/
      </span>
      or
      <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
       /md/
      </span>
      or
      <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
       /emad/
      </span>
      ),
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-6">
       <a href="#cite_note-6">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        6
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-7">
       <a href="#cite_note-7">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        7
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-8">
       <a href="#cite_note-8">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        8
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      abbreviated
      <b>
       LSD
      </b>
      or
      <b>
       LSD-25
      </b>
      , also known as
      <b>
       lysergide
      </b>
      (
      <a href="/wiki/International_Nonproprietary_Name" title="International Nonproprietary Name">
       INN
      </a>
      ) and colloquially as
      <b>
       acid
      </b>
      , is a
      <a href="/wiki/Psychedelic_drug" title="Psychedelic drug">
       psychedelic drug
      </a>
      of the
      <a href="/wiki/Ergoline" title="Ergoline">
       ergoline
      </a>
      family, well known for its psychological effects - which can include altered thinking processes, closed- and open-eye visuals,
      <a href="/wiki/Synesthesia" title="Synesthesia">
       synesthesia
      </a>
      , an altered
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sense_of_time" title="Sense of time">
       sense of time
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Religious_experience" title="Religious experience">
       spiritual experiences
      </a>
      - as well as for its key role in
      <a href="/wiki/Counterculture_of_the_1960s" title="Counterculture of the 1960s">
       1960s counterculture
      </a>
      . It is used mainly as an
      <a href="/wiki/Entheogen" title="Entheogen">
       entheogen
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Recreational_drug_use" title="Recreational drug use">
       recreational drug
      </a>
      . LSD is non-addictive.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pmid17105338_9-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-pmid17105338-9">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        9
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      However, acute adverse psychiatric reactions such as anxiety, paranoia, and delusions are possible.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Passie-2008_10-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Passie-2008-10">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        10
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      LSD was first
      <a href="/wiki/Chemical_synthesis" title="Chemical synthesis">
       synthesized
      </a>
      by
      <a href="/wiki/Albert_Hofmann" title="Albert Hofmann">
       Albert Hofmann
      </a>
      in 1938 from
      <a href="/wiki/Ergotamine" title="Ergotamine">
       ergotamine
      </a>
      , a chemical derived by
      <a href="/wiki/Arthur_Stoll" title="Arthur Stoll">
       Arthur Stoll
      </a>
      from
      <a href="/wiki/Ergot" title="Ergot">
       ergot
      </a>
      , a
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Grain" title="Grain">
       grain
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Fungus" title="Fungus">
       fungus
      </a>
      that typically grows on
      <a href="/wiki/Rye" title="Rye">
       rye
      </a>
      . The short form "LSD" comes from its early code name
      <i>
       LSD-25
      </i>
      , which is an abbreviation for the German "Lysergsure-diethylamid" followed by a sequential number.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-problem-child_11-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-problem-child-11">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        11
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tihkal_12-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-tihkal-12">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        12
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      LSD is sensitive to
      <a href="/wiki/Oxygen" title="Oxygen">
       oxygen
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Ultraviolet" title="Ultraviolet">
       ultraviolet light
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Chlorine" title="Chlorine">
       chlorine
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tihkal_12-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-tihkal-12">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        12
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      especially in
      <a href="/wiki/Solution" title="Solution">
       solution
      </a>
      , though its potency may last for years if it is stored away from light and moisture at low temperature. In pure form it is a colorless, odorless, tasteless solid.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-13">
       <a href="#cite_note-13">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        13
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      LSD is typically either swallowed (
      <a href="/wiki/Mouth" title="Mouth">
       oral
      </a>
      ) or held under the tongue (
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sublingual" title="Sublingual">
       sublingual
      </a>
      ), usually on a substrate such as absorbent
      <a href="/wiki/Blotting_paper" title="Blotting paper">
       blotter paper
      </a>
      , a
      <a href="/wiki/Sugar" title="Sugar">
       sugar cube
      </a>
      , or
      <a href="/wiki/Gelatin" title="Gelatin">
       gelatin
      </a>
      . In its liquid form, it can also be administered by intramuscular or intravenous injection. Interestingly, unlike most other classes of illicit drugs and other groups of
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Psychedelic_drugs" title="Psychedelic drugs">
       psychedelic drugs
      </a>
      such as
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tryptamines" title="Tryptamines">
       tryptamines
      </a>
      and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Phenethylamines" title="Phenethylamines">
       phenethylamines
      </a>
      , when LSD is administered via intravenous injection the onset is not immediate, instead taking approximately 30 minutes before the effects are realized. LSD is very potent, with 2030
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Micrograms" title="Micrograms">
       g
      </a>
      (micrograms) being the threshold dose.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-greiner_14-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-greiner-14">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        14
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Hofmann discovered the psychedelic properties of LSD in 1943.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-15">
       <a href="#cite_note-15">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        15
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      It was introduced commercially in 1947 by
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sandoz_Laboratories" title="Sandoz Laboratories">
       Sandoz Laboratories
      </a>
      under the trade-name
      <b>
       Delysid
      </b>
      as a drug with various
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Psychiatric" title="Psychiatric">
       psychiatric
      </a>
      uses.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-16">
       <a href="#cite_note-16">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        16
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In the 1950s, officials at the U.S.
      <a href="/wiki/Central_Intelligence_Agency" title="Central Intelligence Agency">
       Central Intelligence Agency
      </a>
      (CIA) thought the drug might be applicable to
      <a href="/wiki/Mind_control" title="Mind control">
       mind control
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Chemical_warfare" title="Chemical warfare">
       chemical warfare
      </a>
      ; the agency's
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/MKULTRA" title="MKULTRA">
       MKULTRA
      </a>
      research program propagated the drug among young servicemen and students. The subsequent recreational use of the drug by
      <a href="/wiki/Youth_culture" title="Youth culture">
       youth culture
      </a>
      in the
      <a href="/wiki/Western_world" title="Western world">
       Western world
      </a>
      during the 1960s led to a political firestorm that resulted in its
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Psychedelics,_dissociatives_and_deliriants#Legal_status_and_attitudes" title="Psychedelics, dissociatives and deliriants">
       prohibition
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-17">
       <a href="#cite_note-17">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        17
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="toclimit-3">

         </ul>
        </li>
        <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-26">
         <a href="#History">
          <span class="tocnumber">
           7
          </span>
          <span class="toctext">
           History
          </span>
         </a>
        </li>
        <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-27">
         <a href="#Society_and_culture">
          <span class="tocnumber">
           8
          </span>
          <span class="toctext">
           Society and culture
          </span>
         </a>
         <ul>
          <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-28">
           <a href="#Legal_status">
            <span class="tocnumber">
             8.1
            </span>

            </span>
           </a>
           <ul>
            <li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-29">
             <a href="#Canada">
              <span class="tocnumber">

              </span>
             </a>
            </li>
            <li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-30">
             <a href="#United_Kingdom">
              <span class="tocnumber">

              </span>

               United Kingdom
              </span>
             </a>
            </li>
            <li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-31">
             <a href="#United_States">
              <span class="tocnumber">
               8.1.3
              </span>
              <span class="toctext">
               United States
              </span>
             </a>
            </li>
           </ul>
          </li>
          <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-32">
           <a href="#Economics">
            <span class="tocnumber">
             8.2
            </span>
            <span class="toctext">
             Economics
            </span>
           </a>
           <ul>
            <li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-33">
             <a href="#Production">
              <span class="tocnumber">
               8.2.1
              </span>
              <span class="toctext">
               Production
              </span>
             </a>
             <ul>
              <li class="toclevel-4 tocsection-34">
               <a href="#Forms">
                <span class="tocnumber">
                 8.2.1.1
                </span>
                <span class="toctext">
                 Forms
                </span>
               </a>
              </li>
              <li class="toclevel-4 tocsection-35">
               <a href="#Modern_distribution">

                </span>

                </span>
               </a>
              </li>

            </li>

          </li>
         </ul>
        </li>
        <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-37">
         <a href="#Research">
          <span class="tocnumber">
           9
          </span>
          <span class="toctext">
           Research
          </span>
         </a>
         <ul>
          <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-38">
           <a href="#Therapeutic_use">
            <span class="tocnumber">
             9.1
            </span>
            <span class="toctext">
             Therapeutic use
            </span>
           </a>
           <ul>
            <li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-39">
             <a href="#Psychedelic_therapy">
              <span class="tocnumber">
               9.1.1
              </span>
              <span class="toctext">

             </a>
            </li>

           </ul>
          </li>
          <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-42">

             Pain management
            </span>
           </a>
          </li>
          <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-43">

            </span>
            <span class="toctext">
             Cluster headaches
            </span>
           </a>
          </li>
          <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-44">
           <a href="#Creativity">

            </span>

             Creativity
            </span>
           </a>
          </li>
         </ul>
        </li>
        <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-45">
         <a href="#See_also">
          <span class="tocnumber">
           10
          </span>
          <span class="toctext">
           See also
          </span>
         </a>
        </li>
        <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-46">
         <a href="#References">

          </span>
         </a>
        </li>
        <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-47">

          </span>

          </span>
         </a>
        </li>
        <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-48">
         <a href="#External_links">

           13
          </span>
          <span class="toctext">
           External links
          </span>
         </a>
        </li>
       </ul>
      </div>
     </div>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Effects">
       Effects
      </span>
     </h2>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Physical">
       Physical
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:242px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Possible_physical_effects_of_lysergic_acid_diethylamide_(LSD).svg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1060" data-file-width="1098" height="232" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Possible_physical_effects_of_lysergic_acid_diethylamide_%28LSD%29.svg/240px-Possible_physical_effects_of_lysergic_acid_diethylamide_%28LSD%29.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Possible_physical_effects_of_lysergic_acid_diethylamide_%28LSD%29.svg/360px-Possible_physical_effects_of_lysergic_acid_diethylamide_%28LSD%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Possible_physical_effects_of_lysergic_acid_diethylamide_%28LSD%29.svg/480px-Possible_physical_effects_of_lysergic_acid_diethylamide_%28LSD%29.svg.png 2x" width="240"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Possible_physical_effects_of_lysergic_acid_diethylamide_(LSD).svg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Notable physical effects of LSD and their locals of occurrence.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      LSD can cause
      <a href="/wiki/Mydriasis" title="Mydriasis">
       pupil dilation
      </a>
      , reduced appetite, and wakefulness. Other physical reactions to LSD are highly variable and nonspecific, some of which may be secondary to the psychological effects of LSD. Among the reported symptoms are numbness, weakness, nausea,
      <a href="/wiki/Hypothermia" title="Hypothermia">
       hypothermia
      </a>
      or
      <a href="/wiki/Hyperthermia" title="Hyperthermia">
       hyperthermia
      </a>
      , elevated
      <a href="/wiki/Blood_sugar" title="Blood sugar">
       blood sugar
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Goose_bumps" title="Goose bumps">
       goose bumps
      </a>
      , heart rate increase, jaw clenching, perspiration,
      <a href="/wiki/Saliva" title="Saliva">
       saliva
      </a>
      production,
      <a href="/wiki/Mucus" title="Mucus">
       mucus
      </a>
      production, sleeplessness,
      <a href="/wiki/Hyperreflexia" title="Hyperreflexia">
       hyperreflexia
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Tremor" title="Tremor">
       tremors
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
       [
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Identifying_reliable_sources_(medicine)" title="Wikipedia:Identifying reliable sources (medicine)">
         <span title="Material near this tag needs references to reliable medical sources. (June 2015)">
          medical citation needed
         </span>
        </a>
       </i>
       ]
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Psychological">
       Psychological
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      LSD's psychological effects (colloquially called a "
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Acid_trip" title="Acid trip">
       trip
      </a>
      ") vary greatly between persons and places. If the user is in a hostile or otherwise unsettling environment, or is not mentally prepared for the powerful distortions in perception and thought that the drug causes, effects are more likely to be unpleasant than if he or she is in a comfortable environment and has a relaxed, balanced and open mindset.
      <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
       [
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Identifying_reliable_sources_(medicine)" title="Wikipedia:Identifying reliable sources (medicine)">
         <span title="Material near this tag needs references to reliable medical sources. (March 2015)">
          medical citation needed
         </span>
        </a>
       </i>
       ]
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      An LSD trip can have long-term psychological or emotional effects; some users
      <sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">
       [
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Words_to_watch#Unsupported_attributions" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Words to watch">
         <span title="The material near this tag possibly uses too-vague attribution or weasel words. (January 2015)">
          who?
         </span>
        </a>
       </i>
       ]
      </sup>
      report the LSD experience as causing significant long term changes in their personality and life perspective.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-18">
       <a href="#cite_note-18">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        18
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Widely different effects emerge based on what
      <a href="/wiki/Timothy_Leary" title="Timothy Leary">
       Timothy Leary
      </a>
      called
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Set_and_setting" title="Set and setting">
        set and setting
       </a>
      </i>
      ; the "set" being the general mindset of the user, and the "setting" being the physical and social environment in which the drug's effects are experienced.
      <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
       [
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
         <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (January 2015)">
          citation needed
         </span>
        </a>
       </i>
       ]
      </sup>
      Some psychological effects may include a sense that one's thoughts are spiraling into themselves and a loss of a sense of identity or the ego (known as "
      <a href="/wiki/Ego_death" title="Ego death">
       ego death
      </a>
      ").
      <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
       [
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Identifying_reliable_sources_(medicine)" title="Wikipedia:Identifying reliable sources (medicine)">
         <span title="Material near this tag needs references to reliable medical sources. (January 2015)">
          medical citation needed
         </span>
        </a>
       </i>
       ]
      </sup>
      Many users experience a dissolution between themselves and the "outside world".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-linton-langs_19-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-linton-langs-19">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        19
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      This unitive quality may play a role in the spiritual and religious aspects of LSD. The drug sometimes leads to disintegration or restructuring of the user's historical personality and creates a mental state that some users
      <sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">
       [
       <i>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Avoid_weasel_words" title="Wikipedia:Avoid weasel words">
         <span title="Who says this? (January 2015)">
          weaselwords
         </span>
        </a>
       </i>
       ]
      </sup>
      report allows them to have more choice regarding the nature of their own personality.
      <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
       [
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Identifying_reliable_sources_(medicine)" title="Wikipedia:Identifying reliable sources (medicine)">
         <span title="Material near this tag needs references to reliable medical sources. (June 2015)">
          medical citation needed
         </span>
        </a>
       </i>
       ]
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Sensory">
       Sensory
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      Some sensory effects may include an experience of radiant colors, objects and surfaces appearing to ripple or "breathe", colored patterns behind the closed eyelids (
      <a href="/wiki/Eidetic_imagery" title="Eidetic imagery">
       eidetic imagery
      </a>
      ), an altered sense of time (time seems to be stretching, repeating itself, changing speed or stopping), crawling geometric patterns overlaying walls and other objects, and morphing objects.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-linton-langs_19-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-linton-langs-19">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        19
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Some users, including Albert Hofmann, report a strong metallic taste for the duration of the effects.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-20">
       <a href="#cite_note-20">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        20
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      LSD causes an
      <a href="/wiki/Animated_Antics" title="Animated Antics">
       animated
      </a>
      sensory experience of
      <a href="/wiki/Sense" title="Sense">
       senses
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Emotion" title="Emotion">
       emotions
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Memory" title="Memory">
       memories
      </a>
      , time, and
      <a href="/wiki/Awareness" title="Awareness">
       awareness
      </a>
      for 6 to 14 hours, depending on dosage and tolerance. Generally beginning within 30 to 90 minutes after ingestion, the user may experience anything from subtle changes in perception to overwhelming
      <a href="/wiki/Cognitive_shift" title="Cognitive shift">
       cognitive shifts
      </a>
      . Changes in auditory and visual perception are typical.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-linton-langs_19-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-linton-langs-19">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        19
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-21">
       <a href="#cite_note-21">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        21
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Visual effects include the illusion of
      <a href="/wiki/Motion_aftereffect" title="Motion aftereffect">
       movement of static surfaces
      </a>
      ("walls breathing"),
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/After_image" title="After image">
       after image
      </a>
      -like trails of moving objects ("tracers"), the appearance of moving colored geometric patterns (especially with closed eyes), an intensification of colors and brightness ("sparkling"), new textures on objects, blurred vision, and shape suggestibility. Users commonly report
      <sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">
       [
       <i>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Avoid_weasel_words" title="Wikipedia:Avoid weasel words">
         <span title="Who says this? (January 2015)">
          weaselwords
         </span>
        </a>
       </i>
       ]
      </sup>
      that the inanimate world appears to animate in an inexplicable way; for instance, objects that are static in three dimensions can seem to be moving relative to one or more additional spatial dimensions.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-22">
       <a href="#cite_note-22">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        22
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Many of the basic visual effects resemble the
      <a href="/wiki/Phosphene" title="Phosphene">
       phosphenes
      </a>
      seen after applying pressure to the eye and have also been studied under the name "
      <a href="/wiki/Form_constant" title="Form constant">
       form constants
      </a>
      ". The auditory effects of LSD may include
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Echo_(phenomenon)" title="Echo (phenomenon)">
       echo
      </a>
      -like distortions of sounds, changes in ability to discern concurrent auditory stimuli, and a general intensification of the experience of music. Higher doses often cause intense and fundamental distortions of sensory perception such as
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Synaesthesia" title="Synaesthesia">
       synaesthesia
      </a>
      , the experience of additional spatial or temporal dimensions, and temporary
      <a href="/wiki/Dissociation_(psychology)" title="Dissociation (psychology)">
       dissociation
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
       [
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Identifying_reliable_sources_(medicine)" title="Wikipedia:Identifying reliable sources (medicine)">
         <span title="Material near this tag needs references to reliable medical sources. (January 2015)">
          medical citation needed
         </span>
        </a>
       </i>
       ]
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Uses">
       Uses
      </span>
     </h2>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Medical">
       Medical
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote">
      See also:
      <a href="/wiki/Lysergic_acid_diethylamide#Research" title="Lysergic acid diethylamide">
       Lysergic acid diethylamide  Research
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      LSD currently has no recognized medical use.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-23">
       <a href="#cite_note-23">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        23
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Recreational_and_spiritual">
       Recreational and spiritual
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Pink_Elephants_on_Parade_Blotter_LSD_Dumbo.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1200" data-file-width="1683" height="157" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/Pink_Elephants_on_Parade_Blotter_LSD_Dumbo.jpg/220px-Pink_Elephants_on_Parade_Blotter_LSD_Dumbo.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/Pink_Elephants_on_Parade_Blotter_LSD_Dumbo.jpg/330px-Pink_Elephants_on_Parade_Blotter_LSD_Dumbo.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/Pink_Elephants_on_Parade_Blotter_LSD_Dumbo.jpg/440px-Pink_Elephants_on_Parade_Blotter_LSD_Dumbo.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Pink_Elephants_on_Parade_Blotter_LSD_Dumbo.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Pink elephant blotters containing LSD
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Despite its mostly illegal status worldwide, LSD is commonly used as a recreational drug for its psychedelic effects.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-24">
       <a href="#cite_note-24">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        24
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h4>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Entheogen">
       Entheogen
      </span>
     </h4>
     <p>
      LSD is considered an
      <a href="/wiki/Entheogen" title="Entheogen">
       entheogen
      </a>
      because it can catalyze intense spiritual experiences, during which users may feel they have come into contact with a greater spiritual or cosmic order. Users claim to experience lucid sensations where they have "out of body" experiences. In 1966,
      <a href="/wiki/Timothy_Leary" title="Timothy Leary">
       Timothy Leary
      </a>
      established the
      <a href="/wiki/League_for_Spiritual_Discovery" title="League for Spiritual Discovery">
       League for Spiritual Discovery
      </a>
      with LSD as its sacrament.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-25">
       <a href="#cite_note-25">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        25
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-26">
       <a href="#cite_note-26">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        26
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Stanislav_Grof" title="Stanislav Grof">
       Stanislav Grof
      </a>
      has written that religious and mystical experiences observed during LSD sessions appear to be phenomenologically indistinguishable from similar descriptions in the sacred scriptures of the great religions of the world and the secret mystical texts of ancient civilizations.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Grof1979_27-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Grof1979-27">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        27
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Adverse_effects">
       Adverse effects
      </span>
     </h2>
     <p>
      Suicide and acts of violence have been associated with LSD use.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-28">
       <a href="#cite_note-28">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        28
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-29">
       <a href="#cite_note-29">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        29
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Long-term effects include "flashbacks" and a syndrome of long-term perceptual changes that are experienced as distressing
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated92_30-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-autogenerated92-30">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        30
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-31">
       <a href="#cite_note-31">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        31
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      LSD can temporarily impair the ability to fully understand common dangers and therefore users may be more susceptible to personal injury and accidents. LSD may also cause temporary confusion, difficulty with
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Abstract_thinking" title="Abstract thinking">
       abstract thinking
      </a>
      , or signs of impaired memory and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ADHD-PI" title="ADHD-PI">
       attention span
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-32">
       <a href="#cite_note-32">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        32
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Mental_disorders">
       Mental disorders
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      LSD may trigger
      <a href="/wiki/Panic_attack" title="Panic attack">
       panic attacks
      </a>
      or feelings of extreme anxiety, colloquially referred to as a "
      <a href="/wiki/Bad_trip" title="Bad trip">
       bad trip
      </a>
      ". There is evidence that people with severe mental illnesses like
      <a href="/wiki/LSD_and_schizophrenia" title="LSD and schizophrenia">
       schizophrenia
      </a>
      have a higher likelihood of experiencing adverse effects from taking LSD (see psychosis for further details).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-33">
       <a href="#cite_note-33">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        33
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">
       [
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Identifying_reliable_sources_(medicine)" title="Wikipedia:Identifying reliable sources (medicine)">
         <span title="Material near this tag may use an unreliable or less reliable medical source. (January 2015)">
          unreliable medical source
         </span>
        </a>
       </i>
       ]
      </sup>
      No real prolonged effects have been proven, although PTSD has been reported after some intensely distressful LSD experiences.
      <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
       [
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Identifying_reliable_sources_(medicine)" title="Wikipedia:Identifying reliable sources (medicine)">
         <span title="Material near this tag needs references to reliable medical sources. (March 2015)">
          medical citation needed
         </span>
        </a>
       </i>
       ]
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Suggestibility">
       Suggestibility
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      While publicly available documents indicate that the
      <a href="/wiki/Central_Intelligence_Agency" title="Central Intelligence Agency">
       CIA
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Defense" title="United States Department of Defense">
       Department of Defense
      </a>
      have discontinued research into the use of LSD as a means of mind control,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-34">
       <a href="#cite_note-34">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        34
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      research from the 1960s suggests there exists evidence that both mentally ill and healthy people are more
      <a href="/wiki/Suggestibility" title="Suggestibility">
       suggestible
      </a>
      while under its influence.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-35">
       <a href="#cite_note-35">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        35
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-36">
       <a href="#cite_note-36">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        36
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="noprint Inline-Template noprint Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
       [
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:No_original_research#Primary.2C_secondary_and_tertiary_sources" title="Wikipedia:No original research">
         <span title="This claim needs references to reliable secondary sources. (January 2015)">
          non-primary source needed
         </span>
        </a>
       </i>
       ]
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Psychosis">
       Psychosis
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      Historical data suggests that there has been the occasional incidence of long-term LSD induced
      <a href="/wiki/Psychosis" title="Psychosis">
       psychosis
      </a>
      in people who appeared to be healthy prior to taking the drug.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-37">
       <a href="#cite_note-37">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        37
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Flashbacks_and_HPPD">
       Flashbacks and HPPD
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote">
      See also:
      <a href="/wiki/Flashback_(psychology)" title="Flashback (psychology)">
       Flashback (psychology)
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      "Flashbacks" are a reported psychological phenomenon in which an individual experiences an episode of some of LSD's subjective effects long after the drug has worn off, usually in the days after typical doses.
      <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
       [
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Identifying_reliable_sources_(medicine)" title="Wikipedia:Identifying reliable sources (medicine)">
         <span title="Material near this tag needs references to reliable medical sources. (January 2015)">
          medical citation needed
         </span>
        </a>
       </i>
       ]
      </sup>
      Several studies have tried to determine how likely a user of LSD, not suffering from known psychiatric conditions, is to experience flashbacks. The larger studies include Blumenfeld's in 1971
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-38">
       <a href="#cite_note-38">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        38
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="noprint Inline-Template noprint Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
       [
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:No_original_research#Primary.2C_secondary_and_tertiary_sources" title="Wikipedia:No original research">
         <span title="This claim needs references to reliable secondary sources. (January 2015)">
          non-primary source needed
         </span>
        </a>
       </i>
       ]
      </sup>
      and Naditch and Fenwick's in 1977,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-39">
       <a href="#cite_note-39">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        39
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="noprint Inline-Template noprint Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
       [
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:No_original_research#Primary.2C_secondary_and_tertiary_sources" title="Wikipedia:No original research">
         <span title="This claim needs references to reliable secondary sources. (January 2015)">
          non-primary source needed
         </span>
        </a>
       </i>
       ]
      </sup>
      which arrived at figures of 20% and 28%, respectively.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-40">
       <a href="#cite_note-40">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        40
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">
       [
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Identifying_reliable_sources_(medicine)" title="Wikipedia:Identifying reliable sources (medicine)">
         <span title="Material near this tag may use an unreliable or less reliable medical source. (January 2015)">
          unreliable medical source
         </span>
        </a>
       </i>
       ]
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated92_30-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-autogenerated92-30">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        30
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-41">
       <a href="#cite_note-41">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        41
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      <a href="/wiki/Hallucinogen_persisting_perception_disorder" title="Hallucinogen persisting perception disorder">
       Hallucinogen Persisting Perception Disorder
      </a>
      (HPPD) describes a post-LSD exposure syndrome which LSD-like visual changes are not temporary and brief, as they are in flashbacks, but instead are persistent, and cause clinically significant impairment or distress. The syndrome is a
      <a href="/wiki/Diagnostic_and_Statistical_Manual_of_Mental_Disorders" title="Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders">
       DSM-IV
      </a>
      diagnosis. Several scientific journal articles have described the disorder.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-42">
       <a href="#cite_note-42">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        42
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      HPPD differs from flashbacks in that it is persistent and apparently entirely visual (although mood and anxiety disorders are sometimes diagnosed in the same individuals). A recent review suggests that
      <a href="/wiki/Hallucinogen_persisting_perception_disorder" title="Hallucinogen persisting perception disorder">
       HPPD
      </a>
      (as defined in the DSM-IV) is uncommon and affects a distinctly vulnerable subpopulation of users.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-43">
       <a href="#cite_note-43">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        43
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-44">
       <a href="#cite_note-44">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        44
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Uterine_contractions">
       Uterine contractions
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      Early pharmacological testing by Sandoz in laboratory animals showed that LSD can stimulate uterine contractions, with efficacy comparable to
      <a href="/wiki/Ergoline#Lysergic_acid_amides" title="Ergoline">
       ergobasine
      </a>
      , the active uterotonic component of the
      <a href="/wiki/Ergot" title="Ergot">
       ergot
      </a>
      fungus.
      <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
       [
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Identifying_reliable_sources_(medicine)" title="Wikipedia:Identifying reliable sources (medicine)">
         <span title="Material near this tag needs references to reliable medical sources. (January 2015)">
          medical citation needed
         </span>
        </a>
       </i>
       ]
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Genetic">
       Genetic
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      The mutagenic potential of LSD is unclear. Overall, the evidence seems to point to limited or no effect at commonly used doses.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-45">
       <a href="#cite_note-45">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        45
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Addiction_and_tolerance">
       Addiction and tolerance
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      LSD is not considered addictive by the medical community.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pmid17105338_9-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-pmid17105338-9">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        9
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Tolerance to LSD-25 builds up over consistent use
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-springer_46-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-springer-46">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        46
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Cross-tolerance" title="Cross-tolerance">
       cross-tolerance
      </a>
      has been demonstrated between LSD,
      <a href="/wiki/Mescaline" title="Mescaline">
       mescaline
      </a>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-isbell_mescaline_47-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-isbell_mescaline-47">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        47
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Psilocybin" title="Psilocybin">
       psilocybin
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-isbell_psilocybin_48-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-isbell_psilocybin-48">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        48
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      This tolerance diminishes a few days after cessation of use and is probably caused by
      <a href="/wiki/Downregulation_and_upregulation" title="Downregulation and upregulation">
       downregulation
      </a>
      of
      <a href="/wiki/5-HT2A_receptor" title="5-HT2A receptor">
       5-HT
       <sub>
        2A
       </sub>
       receptors
      </a>
      in the brain.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-49">
       <a href="#cite_note-49">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        49
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-50">
       <a href="#cite_note-50">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        50
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Overdose">
       Overdose
      </span>
     </h2>
     <p>
      Reassurance in a calm, safe environment is beneficial. Agitation can be safely addressed with
      <a href="/wiki/Benzodiazepine" title="Benzodiazepine">
       benzodiazepines
      </a>
      such as
      <a href="/wiki/Diazepam" title="Diazepam">
       diazepam
      </a>
      .
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Neuroleptic" title="Neuroleptic">
       Neuroleptics
      </a>
      such as
      <a href="/wiki/Haloperidol" title="Haloperidol">
       haloperidol
      </a>
      reduce hallucinations and paranoid delusions and can be used to terminate the effects of LSD. LSD is rapidly absorbed, so activated charcoal and emptying of the stomach will be of little benefit. Sedation or physical restraint is rarely required, and excessive restraint may cause complications such as
      <a href="/wiki/Hyperthermia" title="Hyperthermia">
       hyperthermia
      </a>
      (over-heating) or
      <a href="/wiki/Rhabdomyolysis" title="Rhabdomyolysis">
       rhabdomyolysis
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Medscape_51-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Medscape-51">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        51
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Massive doses require supportive care, which may include
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Endotracheal_intubation" title="Endotracheal intubation">
       endotracheal intubation
      </a>
      or respiratory support. Overdose has been recorded at 1,000 to 7,000g per 100ml &amp; 2.1 to 26ng per ml in serum concentrations of the tartrate salt form. High blood pressure,
      <a href="/wiki/Tachycardia" title="Tachycardia">
       tachycardia
      </a>
      (rapid heart-beat) and hyperthermia, if present, should be treated symptomatically. Treat low blood pressure initially with fluids and then with
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pressor" title="Pressor">
       pressors
      </a>
      if necessary. Intravenous administration of
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anticoagulants" title="Anticoagulants">
       anticoagulants
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vasodilators" title="Vasodilators">
       vasodilators
      </a>
      , and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sympatholytics" title="Sympatholytics">
       sympatholytics
      </a>
      may be useful with massive doses.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-52">
       <a href="#cite_note-52">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        52
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Pharmacology">
       Pharmacology
      </span>
     </h2>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Pharmacokinetics">
       Pharmacokinetics
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      LSD's effects normally last from 612 hours depending on dosage, tolerance, body weight and age.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tihkal_12-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-tihkal-12">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        12
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The Sandoz prospectus for "Delysid" warned: "intermittent disturbances of affect may occasionally persist for several days."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-problem-child_11-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-problem-child-11">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        11
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Contrary to early reports and common belief, LSD effects do not last longer than the amount of time significant levels of the drug are present in the blood. Aghajanian and Bing (1964) found LSD had an elimination half-life of only 175 minutes.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Aghajanian_4-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Aghajanian-4">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        4
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      However, using more accurate techniques, Papac and Foltz (1990) reported that 1g/kg oral LSD given to a single male volunteer had an apparent plasma half-life of 5.1 hours, with a peak plasma concentration of 5ng/mL at 3 hours post-dose.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Papac_5-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Papac-5">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        5
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Pharmacodynamics">
       Pharmacodynamics
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:LSDaffinities.GIF">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="503" data-file-width="781" height="142" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/2/20/LSDaffinities.GIF/220px-LSDaffinities.GIF" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/2/20/LSDaffinities.GIF/330px-LSDaffinities.GIF 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/2/20/LSDaffinities.GIF/440px-LSDaffinities.GIF 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:LSDaffinities.GIF" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Binding affinities of LSD for various receptors. The lower the
        <a href="/wiki/Dissociation_constant" title="Dissociation constant">
         dissociation constant
        </a>
        (K
        <sub>
         i
        </sub>
        ), the more strongly LSD binds to that receptor (i.e. with higher affinity). The horizontal line represents an approximate value for human plasma concentrations of LSD, and hence, receptor affinities that are above the line are unlikely to be involved in LSD's effect. Data averaged from data from the
        <a href="/wiki/Ki_Database" title="Ki Database">
         K
         <sub>
          i
         </sub>
         Database
        </a>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      LSD affects a large number of the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/G_protein-coupled_receptor" title="G protein-coupled receptor">
       G protein-coupled
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Receptor_(biochemistry)" title="Receptor (biochemistry)">
       receptors
      </a>
      , including all
      <a href="/wiki/Dopamine_receptor" title="Dopamine receptor">
       dopamine receptor
      </a>
      subtypes, and all
      <a href="/wiki/Adrenergic_receptor" title="Adrenergic receptor">
       adrenoreceptor
      </a>
      subtypes, as well as many others.
      <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
       [
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
         <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (August 2013)">
          citation needed
         </span>
        </a>
       </i>
       ]
      </sup>
      Most
      <a href="/wiki/Psychedelic_drug#Serotonergic_or_classical_psychedelics_.285-HT2A_receptor_agonists.29" title="Psychedelic drug">
       serotonergic psychedelics
      </a>
      are not significantly
      <a href="/wiki/Dopaminergic" title="Dopaminergic">
       dopaminergic
      </a>
      , and LSD is therefore rather unique in this regard. LSD's agonism of
      <a href="/wiki/Dopamine_receptor_D2" title="Dopamine receptor D2">
       D
       <sub>
        2
       </sub>
       receptors
      </a>
      contributes to its psychoactive effects.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nichols_closes_shop_53-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-nichols_closes_shop-53">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        53
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-54">
       <a href="#cite_note-54">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        54
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      LSD binds to most
      <a href="/wiki/5-HT_receptor" title="5-HT receptor">
       serotonin receptor
      </a>
      subtypes except for
      <a href="/wiki/5-HT3_receptor" title="5-HT3 receptor">
       5-HT
       <sub>
        3
       </sub>
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/5-HT4_receptor" title="5-HT4 receptor">
       5-HT
       <sub>
        4
       </sub>
      </a>
      . However, most of these receptors are affected at too low affinity to be sufficiently activated by the brain concentration of approximately 1020
      <a href="/wiki/Molar_concentration" title="Molar concentration">
       nM
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nichols_55-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-nichols-55">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        55
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In humans, recreational doses of LSD can affect
      <a href="/wiki/5-HT1A_receptor" title="5-HT1A receptor">
       5-HT
       <sub>
        1A
       </sub>
      </a>
      (K
      <sub>
       i
      </sub>
      =1.1nM),
      <a href="/wiki/5-HT2A_receptor" title="5-HT2A receptor">
       5-HT
       <sub>
        2A
       </sub>
      </a>
      (K
      <sub>
       i
      </sub>
      =2.9nM),
      <a href="/wiki/5-HT2B_receptor" title="5-HT2B receptor">
       5-HT
       <sub>
        2B
       </sub>
      </a>
      (K
      <sub>
       i
      </sub>
      =4.9nM),
      <a href="/wiki/5-HT2C_receptor" title="5-HT2C receptor">
       5-HT
       <sub>
        2C
       </sub>
      </a>
      (K
      <sub>
       i
      </sub>
      =23nM),
      <a href="/wiki/5-HT5A_receptor" title="5-HT5A receptor">
       5-HT
       <sub>
        5A
       </sub>
      </a>
      (K
      <sub>
       i
      </sub>
      =9nM [in cloned rat tissues]), and
      <a href="/wiki/5-HT6_receptor" title="5-HT6 receptor">
       5-HT
       <sub>
        6
       </sub>
       receptors
      </a>
      (K
      <sub>
       i
      </sub>
      =2.3nM).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Aghajanian_4-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-Aghajanian-4">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        4
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-56">
       <a href="#cite_note-56">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        56
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/5-HT5B_receptor" title="5-HT5B receptor">
       5-HT
       <sub>
        5B
       </sub>
       receptors
      </a>
      , which are not present in humans, also have a high affinity for LSD.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-57">
       <a href="#cite_note-57">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        57
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The psychedelic effects of LSD are attributed to
      <a href="/wiki/Crosstalk_(biology)" title="Crosstalk (biology)">
       cross-activation
      </a>
      of 5-HT
      <sub>
       2A
      </sub>
      <a href="/wiki/GPCR_oligomer" title="GPCR oligomer">
       receptor heteromers
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-58">
       <a href="#cite_note-58">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        58
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Many but not all 5-HT
      <sub>
       2A
      </sub>
      <a href="/wiki/Agonist" title="Agonist">
       agonists
      </a>
      are psychedelics and 5-HT
      <sub>
       2A
      </sub>
      <a href="/wiki/Receptor_antagonist" title="Receptor antagonist">
       antagonists
      </a>
      block the psychedelic activity of LSD. LSD exhibits
      <a href="/wiki/Functional_selectivity" title="Functional selectivity">
       functional selectivity
      </a>
      at the 5-HT
      <sub>
       2A
      </sub>
      and 5HT
      <sub>
       2C
      </sub>
      receptors in that it activates the
      <a href="/wiki/Signal_transduction" title="Signal transduction">
       signal transduction
      </a>
      enzyme
      <a href="/wiki/Phospholipase_A2" title="Phospholipase A2">
       phospholipase A2
      </a>
      instead of activating the enzyme
      <a href="/wiki/Phospholipase_C" title="Phospholipase C">
       phospholipase C
      </a>
      as the endogenous ligand serotonin does.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-59">
       <a href="#cite_note-59">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        59
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Exactly how LSD produces its effects is unknown, but it is thought that it works by increasing
      <a href="/wiki/Glutamic_acid" title="Glutamic acid">
       glutamate
      </a>
      release in the
      <a href="/wiki/Cerebral_cortex" title="Cerebral cortex">
       cerebral cortex
      </a>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nichols_55-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-nichols-55">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        55
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      and therefore
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/EPSP" title="EPSP">
       excitation
      </a>
      in this area, specifically in layers IV and V.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-60">
       <a href="#cite_note-60">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        60
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      LSD, like many other drugs, has been shown to activate
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/DARPP-32" title="DARPP-32">
       DARPP-32
      </a>
      -related pathways.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-61">
       <a href="#cite_note-61">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        61
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      LSD enhances
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/D2R" title="D2R">
       dopamine D2R
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/GPCR_oligomer" title="GPCR oligomer">
       protomer
      </a>
      recognition and
      <a href="/wiki/Cell_signaling" title="Cell signaling">
       signaling
      </a>
      of D25-HT2A receptor complexes. This mechanism may contribute to the psychotic actions of LSD.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-62">
       <a href="#cite_note-62">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        62
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Physical_and_chemical_properties">
       Physical and chemical properties
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Lysergide_stereoisomers_structural_formulae_v.2.png">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2521" data-file-width="3650" height="152" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/Lysergide_stereoisomers_structural_formulae_v.2.png/220px-Lysergide_stereoisomers_structural_formulae_v.2.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/Lysergide_stereoisomers_structural_formulae_v.2.png/330px-Lysergide_stereoisomers_structural_formulae_v.2.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/Lysergide_stereoisomers_structural_formulae_v.2.png/440px-Lysergide_stereoisomers_structural_formulae_v.2.png 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Lysergide_stereoisomers_structural_formulae_v.2.png" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        The four possible stereoisomers of LSD. Only (+)-LSD is psychoactive.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      LSD is a
      <a href="/wiki/Chirality_(chemistry)" title="Chirality (chemistry)">
       chiral
      </a>
      compound with two
      <a href="/wiki/Stereocenter" title="Stereocenter">
       stereocenters
      </a>
      at the
      <a href="/wiki/Carbon" title="Carbon">
       carbon
      </a>
      atoms C-5 and C-8, so that theoretically four different
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Optical_isomerism" title="Optical isomerism">
       optical isomers
      </a>
      of LSD could exist. LSD, also called (+)-
      <small>
       D
      </small>
      -LSD, has the
      <a href="/wiki/Absolute_configuration" title="Absolute configuration">
       absolute configuration
      </a>
      (5
      <i>
       R
      </i>
      ,8
      <i>
       R
      </i>
      ). The C-5
      <a href="/wiki/Isomer" title="Isomer">
       isomers
      </a>
      of lysergamides do not exist in nature and are not formed during the synthesis from
      <small>
       D
      </small>
      -lysergic acid.
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Retrosynthesis" title="Retrosynthesis">
       Retrosynthetically
      </a>
      , the C-5 stereocenter could be analysed as having the same configuration of the alpha carbon of the naturally occurring amino acid L-
      <a href="/wiki/Tryptophan" title="Tryptophan">
       tryptophan
      </a>
      , the precursor to all biosynthetic ergoline compounds.
     </p>
     <p>
      However, LSD and iso-LSD, the two C-8 isomers, rapidly interconvert in the presence of
      <a href="/wiki/Base_(chemistry)" title="Base (chemistry)">
       bases
      </a>
      , as the alpha proton is acidic and can be
      <a href="/wiki/Deprotonation" title="Deprotonation">
       deprotonated
      </a>
      and reprotonated. Non-psychoactive iso-LSD which has formed during the synthesis can be separated by
      <a href="/wiki/Chromatography" title="Chromatography">
       chromatography
      </a>
      and can be isomerized to LSD.
     </p>
     <p>
      Pure salts of LSD are
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Triboluminescent" title="Triboluminescent">
       triboluminescent
      </a>
      , emitting small flashes of white light when shaken in the dark.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tihkal_12-3">
       <a href="#cite_note-tihkal-12">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        12
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      LSD is strongly
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fluorescent" title="Fluorescent">
       fluorescent
      </a>
      and will glow bluish-white under
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UV_light" title="UV light">
       UV light
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Synthesis">
       Synthesis
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      LSD is an
      <a href="/wiki/Ergoline" title="Ergoline">
       ergoline
      </a>
      derivative. It is commonly synthesised by reacting
      <a href="/wiki/Diethylamine" title="Diethylamine">
       diethylamine
      </a>
      with an activated form of
      <a href="/wiki/Lysergic_acid" title="Lysergic acid">
       lysergic acid
      </a>
      . Activating reagents include
      <a href="/wiki/Phosphoryl_chloride" title="Phosphoryl chloride">
       phosphoryl chloride
      </a>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-synth1_63-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-synth1-63">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        63
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Peptide_coupling_reagent" title="Peptide coupling reagent">
       peptide coupling reagents
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-synth2_64-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-synth2-64">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        64
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Lysergic acid is made by alkaline
      <a href="/wiki/Hydrolysis" title="Hydrolysis">
       hydrolysis
      </a>
      of lysergamides like
      <a href="/wiki/Ergotamine" title="Ergotamine">
       ergotamine
      </a>
      , a substance usually derived from the
      <a href="/wiki/Ergot" title="Ergot">
       ergot
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Fungus" title="Fungus">
       fungus
      </a>
      on
      <a href="/wiki/Agar_plate" title="Agar plate">
       agar plate
      </a>
      , or theoretically possible, but impractical and uncommon from
      <a href="/wiki/Ergine" title="Ergine">
       ergine
      </a>
      (lysergic acid amide, LSA) extracted from
      <a href="/wiki/Morning_glory" title="Morning glory">
       morning glory
      </a>
      seeds.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-erowid_65-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-erowid-65">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        65
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Lysergic acid can also be produced synthetically, eliminating the need for ergotamines.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-66">
       <a href="#cite_note-66">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        66
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-67">
       <a href="#cite_note-67">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        67
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Dosage">
       Dosage
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:10_strip.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1500" data-file-width="2074" height="159" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/10_strip.jpg/220px-10_strip.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/10_strip.jpg/330px-10_strip.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/10_strip.jpg/440px-10_strip.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:10_strip.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        White on White blotters (WoW)
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      A single dose of LSD may be between 40 and 500 microgramsan amount roughly equal to one-tenth the mass of a grain of sand. Threshold effects can be felt with as little as 25 micrograms of LSD.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-greiner_14-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-greiner-14">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        14
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-68">
       <a href="#cite_note-68">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        68
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Dosages of LSD are measured in
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Micrograms" title="Micrograms">
       micrograms
      </a>
      (g), or millionths of a gram. By comparison, dosages of most drugs, both recreational and medicinal, are measured in
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Milligram" title="Milligram">
       milligrams
      </a>
      (mg), or thousandths of a gram. For example, an active dose of
      <a href="/wiki/Mescaline" title="Mescaline">
       mescaline
      </a>
      , roughly
      <span class="nowrap">
       0.2 to 0.5 g
      </span>
      , has effects comparable to 100g or less of LSD.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-problem-child_11-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-problem-child-11">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        11
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In the mid-1960s, the most important black market LSD manufacturer (
      <a href="/wiki/Owsley_Stanley" title="Owsley Stanley">
       Owsley Stanley
      </a>
      ) distributed acid at a standard concentration of 270g,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LSD_Samples_Analysis_69-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-LSD_Samples_Analysis-69">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        69
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      while street samples of the 1970s contained 30 to 300g. By the 1980s, the amount had reduced to between 100 and 125g, dropping more in the 1990s to the 2080g range,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-henderson-glass_70-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-henderson-glass-70">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        70
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      and even more in the 2000s (decade).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LSD_Samples_Analysis_69-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-LSD_Samples_Analysis-69">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        69
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-71">
       <a href="#cite_note-71">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        71
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Reactivity_and_degradation">
       Reactivity and degradation
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      "LSD," writes the chemist
      <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Shulgin" title="Alexander Shulgin">
       Alexander Shulgin
      </a>
      , "is an unusually fragile molecule...As a salt, in water, cold, and free from air and light exposure, it is stable indefinitely."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tihkal_12-4">
       <a href="#cite_note-tihkal-12">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        12
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      LSD has two labile protons at the tertiary stereogenic C5 and C8 positions, rendering these centres prone to epimerisation. The C8 proton is more labile due to the electron-withdrawing carboxamide attachment, but removal of the chiral proton at the C5 position (which was once also an alpha proton of the parent molecule
      <a href="/wiki/Tryptophan" title="Tryptophan">
       tryptophan
      </a>
      ) is assisted by the inductively withdrawing nitrogen and pi electron delocalisation with the indole ring.
      <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
       [
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
         <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (May 2011)">
          citation needed
         </span>
        </a>
       </i>
       ]
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      LSD also has
      <a href="/wiki/Enamine" title="Enamine">
       enamine
      </a>
      -type reactivity because of the electron-donating effects of the indole ring. Because of this,
      <a href="/wiki/Chlorine" title="Chlorine">
       chlorine
      </a>
      destroys LSD molecules on contact; even though chlorinated tap water contains only a slight amount of chlorine, the small quantity of compound typical to an LSD solution will likely be eliminated when dissolved in tap water.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tihkal_12-5">
