       <a href="#cite_note-tihkal-12">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        12
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Covalent_bond" title="Covalent bond">
       double bond
      </a>
      between the 8-position and the
      <a href="/wiki/Aromatic_hydrocarbon" title="Aromatic hydrocarbon">
       aromatic ring
      </a>
      , being conjugated with the indole ring, is susceptible to nucleophilic attacks by water or alcohol, especially in the presence of light. LSD often converts to "lumi-LSD", which is inactive in human beings.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tihkal_12-6">
       <a href="#cite_note-tihkal-12">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        12
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      A controlled study was undertaken to determine the stability of LSD in pooled urine samples.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-72">
       <a href="#cite_note-72">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        72
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The concentrations of LSD in urine samples were followed over time at various temperatures, in different types of storage containers, at various exposures to different wavelengths of light, and at varying pH values. These studies demonstrated no significant loss in LSD concentration at 25C for up to four weeks. After four weeks of incubation, a 30% loss in LSD concentration at 37C and up to a 40% at 45C were observed. Urine fortified with LSD and stored in amber glass or nontransparent polyethylene containers showed no change in concentration under any light conditions. Stability of LSD in transparent containers under light was dependent on the distance between the light source and the samples, the wavelength of light, exposure time, and the intensity of light. After prolonged exposure to heat in alkaline pH conditions, 10 to 15% of the parent LSD epimerized to iso-LSD. Under acidic conditions, less than 5% of the LSD was converted to iso-LSD. It was also demonstrated that trace amounts of metal ions in buffer or urine could catalyze the decomposition of LSD and that this process can be avoided by the addition of
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/EDTA" title="EDTA">
       EDTA
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Detection_in_body_fluids">
       Detection in body fluids
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      LSD may be quantified in urine as part of a
      <a href="/wiki/Drug_test" title="Drug test">
       drug abuse testing program
      </a>
      , in plasma or serum to confirm a diagnosis of poisoning in hospitalized victims or in whole blood to assist in a forensic investigation of a traffic or other criminal violation or a case of sudden death. Both the parent drug and its major metabolite are unstable in biofluids when exposed to light, heat or alkaline conditions and therefore specimens are protected from light, stored at the lowest possible temperature and analyzed quickly to minimize losses.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-73">
       <a href="#cite_note-73">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        73
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="History">
       History
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="quotebox" style="float: right; clear: right; margin: 0.5em 0 0.8em 1.4em; width:25em; padding: 6px; border: 1px solid #aaa; font-size: 88%; background-color: #F9F9F9;">
      <div class="" style="position: relative; text-align: left;">
       <div>
        <p>
         "... affected by a remarkable restlessness, combined with a slight dizziness. At home I lay down and sank into a not unpleasant intoxicated-like condition, characterized by an extremely stimulated imagination. In a dreamlike state, with eyes closed (I found the daylight to be unpleasantly glaring), I perceived an uninterrupted stream of fantastic pictures, extraordinary shapes with intense,
         <a href="/wiki/Kaleidoscope" title="Kaleidoscope">
          kaleidoscopic
         </a>
         play of colors. After some two hours this condition faded away."
        </p>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div style="text-align: left;">
       Albert Hofmann, on his first experience with LSD
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-74">
        <a href="#cite_note-74">
         <span>
          [
         </span>
         74
         <span>
          ]
         </span>
        </a>
       </sup>
      </div>
     </div>
     <div class="hatnote relarticle mainarticle">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/History_of_lysergic_acid_diethylamide" title="History of lysergic acid diethylamide">
       History of lysergic acid diethylamide
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      LSD was first synthesized on November 16, 1938
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-75">
       <a href="#cite_note-75">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        75
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      by Swiss chemist
      <a href="/wiki/Albert_Hofmann" title="Albert Hofmann">
       Albert Hofmann
      </a>
      at the Sandoz Laboratories in
      <a href="/wiki/Basel" title="Basel">
       Basel
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Switzerland" title="Switzerland">
       Switzerland
      </a>
      as part of a large research program searching for medically useful
      <a href="/wiki/Ergoline" title="Ergoline">
       ergot alkaloid
      </a>
      derivatives. LSD's
      <a href="/wiki/Psychedelic_drug" title="Psychedelic drug">
       psychedelic
      </a>
      properties were discovered 5 years later when Hofmann himself accidentally ingested an unknown quantity of the chemical.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hyponichols_76-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-hyponichols-76">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        76
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The first intentional ingestion of LSD occurred on April 19, 1943,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-77">
       <a href="#cite_note-77">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        77
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      when Hofmann ingested 250
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Micrograms" title="Micrograms">
       g
      </a>
      of LSD. He said this would be a threshold dose based on the dosages of other ergot alkaloids. Hofmann found the effects to be much stronger than he anticipated.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-histlsd_78-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-histlsd-78">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        78
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Sandoz Laboratories introduced LSD as a psychiatric drug in 1947.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-79">
       <a href="#cite_note-79">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        79
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Albert_Hofmann.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="297" data-file-width="400" height="126" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Albert_Hofmann.jpg/170px-Albert_Hofmann.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Albert_Hofmann.jpg/255px-Albert_Hofmann.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Albert_Hofmann.jpg/340px-Albert_Hofmann.jpg 2x" width="170"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Albert_Hofmann.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Albert Hofmann in 2006
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Beginning in the 1950s, the US
      <a href="/wiki/Central_Intelligence_Agency" title="Central Intelligence Agency">
       Central Intelligence Agency
      </a>
      began a research program code named
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Project_MKULTRA" title="Project MKULTRA">
       Project MKULTRA
      </a>
      . Experiments included administering LSD to CIA employees, military personnel, doctors, other government agents, prostitutes, mentally ill patients, and members of the general public in order to study their reactions, usually without the subjects' knowledge. The project was revealed in the US congressional
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/United_States_President%27s_Commission_on_CIA_activities_within_the_United_States" title="United States President's Commission on CIA activities within the United States">
       Rockefeller Commission report
      </a>
      in 1975.
     </p>
     <p>
      In 1963, the Sandoz patents expired on LSD.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-henderson-glass_70-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-henderson-glass-70">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        70
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Several figures, including
      <a href="/wiki/Aldous_Huxley" title="Aldous Huxley">
       Aldous Huxley
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Timothy_Leary" title="Timothy Leary">
       Timothy Leary
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Alfred_Matthew_Hubbard" title="Alfred Matthew Hubbard">
       Al Hubbard
      </a>
      , began to advocate the consumption of LSD. LSD became central to the counterculture of the 1960s.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-80">
       <a href="#cite_note-80">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        80
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      On October 24, 1968, possession of LSD was made illegal in the United States.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-81">
       <a href="#cite_note-81">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        81
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The last
      <a href="/wiki/Food_and_Drug_Administration" title="Food and Drug Administration">
       FDA
      </a>
      approved study of LSD in patients ended in 1980, while a study in healthy volunteers was made in the late 1980s. Legally approved and regulated psychiatric use of LSD continued in Switzerland until 1993.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-82">
       <a href="#cite_note-82">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        82
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Society_and_culture">
       Society and culture
      </span>
     </h2>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Legal_status">
       Legal status
      </span>
     </h3>
     <table class="metadata plainlinks ambox ambox-content ambox-globalize" role="presentation">
      <tr>
       <td class="mbox-image">
        <div style="width:52px">
         <img alt="Globe icon." data-file-height="290" data-file-width="350" height="40" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Ambox_globe_content.svg/48px-Ambox_globe_content.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Ambox_globe_content.svg/73px-Ambox_globe_content.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Ambox_globe_content.svg/97px-Ambox_globe_content.svg.png 2x" width="48"/>
        </div>
       </td>
       <td class="mbox-text">
        <span class="mbox-text-span">
         The examples and perspective in this section
         <b>
          deal primarily with
          <a href="/wiki/English-speaking_world" title="English-speaking world">
           the English-speaking world
          </a>
          and do not represent a
          <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:WikiProject_Countering_systemic_bias" title="Wikipedia:WikiProject Countering systemic bias">
           worldwide view
          </a>
          of the subject
         </b>
         .
         <span class="hide-when-compact">
          Please
          <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Lysergic_acid_diethylamide&amp;action=edit">
           improve this article
          </a>
          and discuss the issue on the
          <a href="/wiki/Talk:Lysergic_acid_diethylamide" title="Talk:Lysergic acid diethylamide">
           talk page
          </a>
          .
         </span>
         <small>
          <i>
           (January 2013)
          </i>
         </small>
        </span>
       </td>
      </tr>
     </table>
     <p>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">
       United Nations
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Convention_on_Psychotropic_Substances" title="Convention on Psychotropic Substances">
       Convention on Psychotropic Substances
      </a>
      (adopted in 1971) requires its parties to prohibit LSD. Hence, it is illegal in all parties to the convention, which includes the United States, Australia, New Zealand, and most of Europe. However, enforcement of extant laws varies from country to country. Medical and scientific research with LSD in humans is permitted under the 1971 UN Convention.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-83">
       <a href="#cite_note-83">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        83
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h4>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Canada">
       Canada
      </span>
     </h4>
     <p>
      In
      <a href="/wiki/Canada" title="Canada">
       Canada
      </a>
      , LSD is a controlled substance under Schedule III of the
      <a href="/wiki/Controlled_Drugs_and_Substances_Act" title="Controlled Drugs and Substances Act">
       Controlled Drugs and Substances Act
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cdasa_84-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-cdasa-84">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        84
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Every person who seeks to obtain the substance, without disclosing authorization to obtain such substances 30 days before obtaining another prescription from a practitioner, is guilty of an indictable offense and liable to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 3 years. Possession for purpose of trafficking is an indictable offense punishable by imprisonment for 10 years.
     </p>
     <h4>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="United_Kingdom">
       United Kingdom
      </span>
     </h4>
     <p>
      In the United Kingdom, LSD is a Schedule 1 Class 'A' drug. This means it has no recognised legitimate uses and possession of the drug without a license is punishable with 7 years' imprisonment and/or an unlimited fine, and trafficking is punishable with life imprisonment and an unlimited fine (
      <i>
       see main article on drug punishments
       <a href="/wiki/Misuse_of_Drugs_Act_1971" title="Misuse of Drugs Act 1971">
        Misuse of Drugs Act 1971
       </a>
       ).
      </i>
     </p>
     <p>
      In 2000, after consultation with members of the
      <a href="/wiki/Royal_College_of_Psychiatrists" title="Royal College of Psychiatrists">
       Royal College of Psychiatrists
      </a>
      ' Faculty of Substance Misuse, the UK Police Foundation issued the
      <a href="/wiki/Runciman_Report" title="Runciman Report">
       Runciman Report
      </a>
      which recommended
      <i>
       "the transfer of LSD from Class A to Class B"
      </i>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-85">
       <a href="#cite_note-85">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        85
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In November 2009, the UK
      <a href="/wiki/Transform_Drug_Policy_Foundation" title="Transform Drug Policy Foundation">
       Transform Drug Policy Foundation
      </a>
      released in the House of Commons a guidebook to the legal regulation of drugs,
      <i>
       After the War on Drugs: Blueprint for Regulation
      </i>
      , which details options for regulated distribution and sale of LSD and other psychedelics.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-86">
       <a href="#cite_note-86">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        86
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h4>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="United_States">
       United States
      </span>
     </h4>
     <p>
      LSD is Schedule I in the United States, according to the
      <a href="/wiki/Controlled_Substances_Act" title="Controlled Substances Act">
       Controlled Substances Act
      </a>
      of 1970.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-87">
       <a href="#cite_note-87">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        87
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      This means LSD is illegal to manufacture, buy, possess, process, or distribute without a DEA license. By classifying LSD as a Schedule I substance, the
      <a href="/wiki/Drug_Enforcement_Administration" title="Drug Enforcement Administration">
       Drug Enforcement Administration
      </a>
      holds that LSD meets the following three criteria: it is deemed to have a high potential for abuse; it has no legitimate medical use in treatment; and there is a lack of accepted safety for its use under medical supervision. There are no documented deaths from chemical toxicity; most LSD deaths are a result of behavioral toxicity.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-88">
       <a href="#cite_note-88">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        88
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      There can also be substantial discrepancies between the amount of chemical LSD that one possesses and the amount of possession with which one can be charged in the U.S. This is because LSD is almost always present in a medium (e.g. blotter or neutral liquid), and the amount that can be considered with respect to sentencing is the total mass of the drug and its medium. This discrepancy was the subject of 1995
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/United_States_Supreme_Court" title="United States Supreme Court">
       United States Supreme Court
      </a>
      case,
      <i>
       Neal v. U.S.
      </i>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-89">
       <a href="#cite_note-89">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        89
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Lysergic acid and lysergic acid amide, LSD precursors, are both classified in
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Schedule_III_(US)" title="Schedule III (US)">
       Schedule III
      </a>
      of the Controlled Substances Act. Ergotamine tartrate, a precursor to lysergic acid, is regulated under the
      <a href="/wiki/Chemical_Diversion_and_Trafficking_Act" title="Chemical Diversion and Trafficking Act">
       Chemical Diversion and Trafficking Act
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Economics">
       Economics
      </span>
     </h3>
     <h4>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Production">
       Production
      </span>
     </h4>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:177px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:LSDLabGlassware.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="163" data-file-width="175" height="163" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/d1/LSDLabGlassware.jpg" width="175"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:LSDLabGlassware.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Glassware seized by the DEA
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      An active dose of LSD is very minute, allowing a large number of doses to be synthesized from a comparatively small amount of raw material. Twenty five kilograms of precursor
      <a href="/wiki/Ergotamine" title="Ergotamine">
       ergotamine
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Tartrate" title="Tartrate">
       tartrate
      </a>
      can produce 56kg of pure crystalline LSD; this corresponds to 100million doses. Because the masses involved are so small, concealing and transporting illicit LSD is much easier than smuggling other illegal drugs like
      <a href="/wiki/Cocaine" title="Cocaine">
       cocaine
      </a>
      or
      <a href="/wiki/Cannabis_(drug)" title="Cannabis (drug)">
       cannabis
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DEA-pub_90-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-DEA-pub-90">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        90
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Manufacturing LSD requires laboratory equipment and experience in the field of
      <a href="/wiki/Organic_chemistry" title="Organic chemistry">
       organic chemistry
      </a>
      . It takes two to three days to produce 30 to 100 grams of pure compound. It is believed that LSD is not usually produced in large quantities, but rather in a series of small batches. This technique minimizes the loss of precursor chemicals in case a step does not work as expected.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DEA-pub_90-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-DEA-pub-90">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        90
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="noprint Inline-Template">
       <span style="white-space: nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Link_rot" title="Wikipedia:Link rot">
          <span title="since January 2015">
           dead link
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </span>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h5>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Forms">
       Forms
      </span>
     </h5>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:5_LSD_blotters.png">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="241" data-file-width="620" height="86" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/5_LSD_blotters.png/220px-5_LSD_blotters.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/5_LSD_blotters.png/330px-5_LSD_blotters.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/5_LSD_blotters.png/440px-5_LSD_blotters.png 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:5_LSD_blotters.png" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Five doses of LSD, often called a "five strip"
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      LSD is produced in crystalline form and then mixed with
      <a href="/wiki/Excipient" title="Excipient">
       excipients
      </a>
      or redissolved for production in ingestible forms. Liquid solution is either distributed in small vials or, more commonly, sprayed onto or soaked into a distribution medium. Historically, LSD solutions were first sold on sugar cubes, but practical considerations forced a change to
      <a href="/wiki/Tablet_(pharmacy)" title="Tablet (pharmacy)">
       tablet
      </a>
      form. Appearing in 1968 as an orange tablet measuring about 6mm across, "Orange Sunshine" acid was the first largely available form of LSD after its possession was made illegal.
      <a href="/wiki/Tim_Scully" title="Tim Scully">
       Tim Scully
      </a>
      , a prominent chemist, made some of these tablets, but said that most "Sunshine" in the USA came by way of
      <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Ronald_Stark&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Ronald Stark (page does not exist)">
       Ronald Stark
      </a>
      , who imported approximately thirty-five million doses from Europe.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Stafford1992_91-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Stafford1992-91">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        91
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Over a period of time, tablet dimensions, weight, shape and concentration of LSD evolved from large (4.58.1mm diameter), heavyweight (150mg), round, high concentration (90350g/tab) dosage units to small (2.03.5mm diameter) lightweight (as low as 4.7mg/tab), variously shaped, lower concentration (1285g/tab, average range 3040g/tab) dosage units. LSD tablet shapes have included cylinders, cones, stars, spacecraft, and heart shapes. The smallest tablets became known as "Microdots".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Laing2003_92-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Laing2003-92">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        92
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      After tablets came "computer acid" or "blotter paper LSD", typically made by dipping a preprinted sheet of
      <a href="/wiki/Blotting_paper" title="Blotting paper">
       blotting paper
      </a>
      into an LSD/water/alcohol solution.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Stafford1992_91-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Stafford1992-91">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        91
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Laing2003_92-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Laing2003-92">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        92
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      More than 200 types of LSD tablets have been encountered since 1969 and more than 350 blotter paper designs have been observed since 1975.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Laing2003_92-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-Laing2003-92">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        92
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      About the same time as blotter paper LSD came "Windowpane" (AKA "Clearlight"), which contained LSD inside a thin
      <a href="/wiki/Gelatin" title="Gelatin">
       gelatin
      </a>
      square a quarter of an inch (6mm) across.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Stafford1992_91-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-Stafford1992-91">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        91
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      LSD has been sold under a wide variety of often short-lived and regionally restricted street names including Acid, Trips, Uncle Sid, Blotter,
      <a href="/wiki/Lucy_in_the_Sky_with_Diamonds" title="Lucy in the Sky with Diamonds">
       Lucy
      </a>
      , Alice and doses, as well as names that reflect the designs on the sheets of blotter paper.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-erowid-faq_93-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-erowid-faq-93">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        93
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-94">
       <a href="#cite_note-94">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        94
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Authorities have encountered the drug in other formsincluding powder or crystal, and capsule.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-95">
       <a href="#cite_note-95">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        95
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h5>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Modern_distribution">
       Modern distribution
      </span>
     </h5>
     <p>
      LSD manufacturers and traffickers in the
      <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">
       United States
      </a>
      can be categorized into two groups: A few large-scale producers, and an equally limited number of small, clandestine chemists, consisting of independent producers who, operating on a comparatively limited scale, can be found throughout the country.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-96">
       <a href="#cite_note-96">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        96
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      As a group, independent producers are of less concern to the
      <a href="/wiki/Drug_Enforcement_Administration" title="Drug Enforcement Administration">
       Drug Enforcement Administration
      </a>
      than the larger groups, as their product reaches only local markets.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-97">
       <a href="#cite_note-97">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        97
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h5>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Mimics">
       Mimics
      </span>
     </h5>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:177px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Docpsychadelic.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="160" data-file-width="175" height="160" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/3/3f/Docpsychadelic.jpg" width="175"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Docpsychadelic.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        LSD blotter acid mimic actually containing DOC
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Lysergic.JPG">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1920" data-file-width="2560" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/Lysergic.JPG/220px-Lysergic.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/Lysergic.JPG/330px-Lysergic.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/Lysergic.JPG/440px-Lysergic.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Lysergic.JPG" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Different blotters which could possibly be mimics
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Since 2005, law enforcement in the United States and elsewhere has seized several chemicals and combinations of chemicals in blotter paper which were sold as LSD mimics, including
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2,5-dimethoxy-4-bromoamphetamine" title="2,5-dimethoxy-4-bromoamphetamine">
       DOB
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-microgram_october_2005_98-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-microgram_october_2005-98">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        98
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-microgram_november_2006_99-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-microgram_november_2006-99">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        99
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      a mixture of
      <a href="/wiki/2,5-Dimethoxy-4-chloroamphetamine" title="2,5-Dimethoxy-4-chloroamphetamine">
       DOC
      </a>
      and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2,5-dimethoxy-4-iodoamphetamine" title="2,5-dimethoxy-4-iodoamphetamine">
       DOI
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-microgram_march_2008_100-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-microgram_march_2008-100">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        100
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/25I-NBOMe" title="25I-NBOMe">
       25I-NBOMe
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ACMD_Report_101-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-ACMD_Report-101">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        101
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      and a mixture of
      <a href="/wiki/2,5-Dimethoxy-4-chloroamphetamine" title="2,5-Dimethoxy-4-chloroamphetamine">
       DOC
      </a>
      and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2,5-dimethoxy-4-bromoamphetamine" title="2,5-dimethoxy-4-bromoamphetamine">
       DOB
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-microgram_march_2009_102-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-microgram_march_2009-102">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        102
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Street users of LSD are often under the impression that blotter paper which is actively hallucinogenic can only be LSD because that is the only chemical with low enough doses to fit on a small square of blotter paper. While it is true that LSD requires lower doses than most other hallucinogens, blotter paper is capable of absorbing a much larger amount of material. The DEA performed a
      <a href="/wiki/Chromatography" title="Chromatography">
       chromatographic
      </a>
      analysis of blotter paper containing
      <a href="/wiki/2C-C" title="2C-C">
       2C-C
      </a>
      which showed that the paper contained a much greater concentration of the active chemical than typical LSD doses, although the exact quantity was not determined.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-microgram_november_2005_103-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-microgram_november_2005-103">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        103
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Blotter LSD mimics can have relatively small dose squares; a sample of blotter paper containing
      <a href="/wiki/2,5-Dimethoxy-4-chloroamphetamine" title="2,5-Dimethoxy-4-chloroamphetamine">
       DOC
      </a>
      seized by
      <a href="/wiki/Concord,_California" title="Concord, California">
       Concord, California
      </a>
      police had dose markings approximately 6mm apart.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-microgram_december_2007_104-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-microgram_december_2007-104">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        104
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Research">
       Research
      </span>
     </h2>
     <p>
      Currently, a number of organizationsincluding
      <a href="/wiki/Beckley_Foundation" title="Beckley Foundation">
       the Beckley Foundation
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Multidisciplinary_Association_for_Psychedelic_Studies" title="Multidisciplinary Association for Psychedelic Studies">
       MAPS
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Heffter_Research_Institute" title="Heffter Research Institute">
       Heffter Research Institute
      </a>
      and the
      <a href="/wiki/Albert_Hofmann" title="Albert Hofmann">
       Albert Hofmann
      </a>
      Foundationexist to fund, encourage and coordinate research into the medicinal and spiritual uses of LSD and related psychedelics.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-105">
       <a href="#cite_note-105">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        105
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      New clinical LSD experiments in humans started in 2009 for the first time in 35 years.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-new_research_106-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-new_research-106">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        106
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In 2001 the
      <a href="/wiki/Drug_Enforcement_Administration" title="Drug Enforcement Administration">
       United States Drug Enforcement Administration
      </a>
      stated that LSD "produces no aphrodisiac effects, does not increase creativity, has no lasting positive effect in treating alcoholics or criminals, does not produce a 'model psychosis', and does not generate immediate personality change."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-107">
       <a href="#cite_note-107">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        107
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      More recently experimental uses of LSD have included the treatment of alcoholism
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-108">
       <a href="#cite_note-108">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        108
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      and pain and cluster headache relief.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated295_109-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-autogenerated295-109">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        109
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      It has also been used for spiritual purposes, and for its putative effects in increasing creativity.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-110">
       <a href="#cite_note-110">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        110
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Therapeutic_use">
       Therapeutic use
      </span>
     </h3>
     <h4>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Psychedelic_therapy">
       Psychedelic therapy
      </span>
     </h4>
     <p>
      In the 1950s and 1960s LSD was used in psychiatry to enhance psychotherapy known as
      <a href="/wiki/Psychedelic_therapy" title="Psychedelic therapy">
       psychedelic therapy
      </a>
      . Some psychiatrists
      <sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">
       [
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Words_to_watch#Unsupported_attributions" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Words to watch">
         <span title="The material near this tag possibly uses too-vague attribution or weasel words. (January 2015)">
          who?
         </span>
        </a>
       </i>
       ]
      </sup>
      believed LSD was especially useful at helping patients to "unblock" repressed subconscious material through other psychotherapeutic methods,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-111">
       <a href="#cite_note-111">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        111
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      and also for treating alcoholism.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-112">
       <a href="#cite_note-112">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        112
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-113">
       <a href="#cite_note-113">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        113
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      One study concluded, "The root of the therapeutic value of the LSD experience is its potential for producing self-acceptance and self-surrender,"
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-114">
       <a href="#cite_note-114">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        114
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      presumably by forcing the user to face issues and problems in that individual's psyche.
     </p>
     <p>
      Two recent reviews concluded that conclusions drawn from most of these early trials are unreliable due serious methodological flaws. These include the absence of adequate control groups, lack of followup, and vague criteria for therapeutic outcome. In many cases studies failed to convincingly demonstrate whether the drug or the therapeutic interaction was responsible for any beneficial effects.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-115">
       <a href="#cite_note-115">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        115
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-116">
       <a href="#cite_note-116">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        116
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h4>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="End-of-life_anxiety">
       End-of-life anxiety
      </span>
     </h4>
     <p>
      Since 2008 there has been ongoing research in Switzerland into using LSD to alleviate anxiety for terminally ill cancer patients coping with their impending deaths.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-117">
       <a href="#cite_note-117">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        117
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h4>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Alcoholism_treatment">
       Alcoholism treatment
      </span>
     </h4>
     <p>
      A 2012 meta-analysis of six randomized controlled trials found evidence that a single dose of LSD in conjunction with various alcoholism treatment programs was associated with a decrease in alcohol abuse, lasting for several months, but no effect was seen at one year. Adverse events included seizure, moderate confusion and agitation, nausea, vomiting, and acting in a bizarre fashion.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-118">
       <a href="#cite_note-118">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        118
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Pain_management">
       Pain management
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      LSD was studied in the 1960s by Eric Kast for
      <a href="/wiki/Pain_management" title="Pain management">
       pain management
      </a>
      as an
      <a href="/wiki/Analgesic" title="Analgesic">
       analgesic
      </a>
      for serious and chronic suffer caused by
      <a href="/wiki/Cancer" title="Cancer">
       cancer
      </a>
      or other major trauma.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-119">
       <a href="#cite_note-119">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        119
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Cluster_headaches">
       Cluster headaches
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      LSD has been used as a treatment for
      <a href="/wiki/Cluster_headache" title="Cluster headache">
       cluster headaches
      </a>
      with positive results in some small studies.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated295_109-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-autogenerated295-109">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        109
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-120">
       <a href="#cite_note-120">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        120
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Creativity">
       Creativity
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      In the 1950s and 1960s, psychiatrists like
      <a href="/wiki/Oscar_Janiger" title="Oscar Janiger">
       Oscar Janiger
      </a>
      explored the potential effect of LSD on creativity. Experimental studies attempted to measure the effect of LSD on creative activity and aesthetic appreciation.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PMID18562421_121-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-PMID18562421-121">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        121
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PMID2723891_122-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-PMID2723891-122">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        122
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Stafford-Golightly_123-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Stafford-Golightly-123">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        123
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PMID6054248_124-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-PMID6054248-124">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        124
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Seventy professional artists were asked to draw two pictures of a Hopi Indian kachina doll, one before ingesting LSD and one after.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-125">
       <a href="#cite_note-125">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        125
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">
       See also
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="div-col columns column-width" style="-moz-column-width: 30em; -webkit-column-width: 30em; column-width: 30em;">
      <ul>
       <li>

        </a>
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/AL-LAD" title="AL-LAD">
         AL-LAD
        </a>
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/ETH-LAD" title="ETH-LAD">
         ETH-LAD
        </a>
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/LSD_art" title="LSD art">
         LSD art
        </a>
        , on the effect of LSD on drawing and painting
       </li>
       <li>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/LSZ" title="LSZ">

        </a>
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Methysergide" title="Methysergide">

        </a>
        , headache medication, chemically related to LSD
       </li>

        <a href="/wiki/PRO-LAD" title="PRO-LAD">

        </a>

       <li>

        </a>
       </li>
      </ul>
     </div>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="References">
       References
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="reflist columns references-column-width" style="-moz-column-width: 35em; -webkit-column-width: 35em; column-width: 35em; list-style-type: decimal;">
      <ol class="references">
       <li id="cite_note-1">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-1">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <span class="citation book">
          <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.ca/books?id=qfrLBQAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA222" rel="nofollow">
           <i>
            Introduction to Pharmacology Third Edition
           </i>
          </a>
          . Abingdon: CRC Press. 2007. pp.222223.
          <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">
           ISBN
          </a>
          <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9781420047424" title="Special:BookSources/9781420047424">
           9781420047424
          </a>
          .
         </span>
         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ALysergic+acid+diethylamide&amp;rft.btitle=Introduction+to+Pharmacology+Third+Edition&amp;rft.date=2007&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.ca%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DqfrLBQAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPA222&amp;rft.isbn=9781420047424&amp;rft.pages=222-223&amp;rft.place=Abingdon&amp;rft.pub=CRC+Press&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook">
          <span style="display:none;">
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </li>
       <li id="cite_note-NHM-MDMA-2">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-NHM-MDMA_2-0">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <span class="citation book">
          Malenka RC, Nestler EJ, Hyman SE (2009). "Chapter 15: Reinforcement and Addictive Disorders". In Sydor A, Brown RY.
          <i>
           Molecular Neuropharmacology: A Foundation for Clinical Neuroscience
          </i>
          (2nd ed.). New York: McGraw-Hill Medical. p.375.
          <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">
           ISBN
          </a>
          <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9780071481274" title="Special:BookSources/9780071481274">
           9780071481274
          </a>
          .
          <q>
           Several other classes of drugs are categorized as drugs of abuse but rarely produce compulsive use. These include psychedelic agents, such as lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD), which are used for their ability to produce perceptual distortions at low and moderate doses. The use of these drugs is associated with the rapid development of tolerance and the absence of positive reinforcement (Chapter 6). Partial agonist effects at 5HT2A receptors are implicated in the psychedelic actions of LSD and related hallucinogens. 3,4-Methylenedioxymethamphetamine (MDMA), commonly called ecstasy, is an amphetamine derivative. It produces a combination of psychostimulant-like and weak LSD-like effects at low doses. Unlike LSD, MDMA is reinforcingmost likely because of its interactions with dopamine systemsand accordingly is subject to compulsive abuse. The weak psychedelic effects of MDMA appear to result from its amphetamine-like actions on the serotonin reuptake transporter, by means of which it causes transporter-dependent serotonin efflux. MDMA has been proven to produce lesions of serotonin neurons in animals and humans.
          </q>
         </span>
         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ALysergic+acid+diethylamide&amp;rft.atitle=Chapter+15%3A+Reinforcement+and+Addictive+Disorders&amp;rft.aulast=Malenka+RC%2C+Nestler+EJ%2C+Hyman+SE&amp;rft.au=Malenka+RC%2C+Nestler+EJ%2C+Hyman+SE&amp;rft.btitle=Molecular+Neuropharmacology%3A+A+Foundation+for+Clinical+Neuroscience&amp;rft.date=2009&amp;rft.edition=2nd&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.isbn=9780071481274&amp;rft.pages=375&amp;rft.place=New+York&amp;rft.pub=McGraw-Hill+Medical&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook">
          <span style="display:none;">
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </li>
       <li id="cite_note-3">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-3">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <span class="citation book">
          Halpern, John H.; Suzuki, Joji; Huertas,, Pedro E.; Passie, Torsten (7 June 2014). Price, Lawrence H.; Stolerman, Ian P., eds.
          <a class="external text" href="http://link.springer.com/referenceworkentry/10.1007/978-3-642-27772-6_43-2" rel="nofollow">
           <i>
            Encyclopedia of Psychopharmacology A Springer Live Reference
           </i>
          </a>
          . Heidelberg, Germany: Springer-Verlag Berlin Heidelberg. pp.15.
          <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">
           ISBN
          </a>
          <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-3-642-27772-6" title="Special:BookSources/978-3-642-27772-6">
           978-3-642-27772-6
          </a>
          <span class="reference-accessdate">
           . Retrieved
           <span class="nowrap">
            24 April
           </span>
           2015
          </span>
          .
          <q>
           Hallucinogen abuse and dependence are known complications resulting from the illicit use of drugs in this category, such as LSD and psilocybin. Users do not experience withdrawal symptoms, but the general criteria for substance abuse and dependence otherwise apply. Dependence is estimated in approximately 2% of recent-onset users in the United States.
          </q>
         </span>
         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ALysergic+acid+diethylamide&amp;rft.aufirst=John+H.&amp;rft.au=Halpern%2C+John+H.&amp;rft.au=Huertas%2C%2C+Pedro+E.&amp;rft.aulast=Halpern&amp;rft.au=Passie%2C+Torsten&amp;rft.au=Suzuki%2C+Joji&amp;rft.btitle=Encyclopedia+of+Psychopharmacology+A+Springer+Live+Reference&amp;rft.date=7+June+2014&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Flink.springer.com%2Freferenceworkentry%2F10.1007%2F978-3-642-27772-6_43-2&amp;rft.isbn=978-3-642-27772-6&amp;rft.pages=1-5&amp;rft.place=Heidelberg%2C+Germany&amp;rft.pub=Springer-Verlag+Berlin+Heidelberg&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook">
          <span style="display:none;">
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </li>
       <li id="cite_note-Aghajanian-4">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         ^
         <a href="#cite_ref-Aghajanian_4-0">
          <sup>
           <i>
            <b>
             a
            </b>
           </i>
          </sup>
         </a>
         <a href="#cite_ref-Aghajanian_4-1">
          <sup>
           <i>
            <b>
             b
            </b>
           </i>
          </sup>
         </a>
         <a href="#cite_ref-Aghajanian_4-2">
          <sup>
           <i>
            <b>
             c
            </b>
           </i>
          </sup>
         </a>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <span class="citation journal">
          Aghajanian GK, Bing OH (1964).
          <a class="external text" href="http://www.maps.org/w3pb/new/1964/1964_aghajanian_2224_1.pdf" rel="nofollow">
           "Persistence of lysergic acid diethylamide in the plasma of human subjects"
          </a>
          <span style="font-size:85%;">
           (PDF)
          </span>
          .
          <i>
           Clinical Pharmacology and Therapeutics
          </i>
          <b>
           5
          </b>
          : 611614.
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/PubMed_Identifier" title="PubMed Identifier">
           PMID
          </a>
          <a class="external text" href="//www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/14209776" rel="nofollow">
           14209776
          </a>
          <span class="reference-accessdate">
           . Retrieved
           <span class="nowrap">
            September 17,
           </span>
           2009
          </span>
          .
         </span>
         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ALysergic+acid+diethylamide&amp;rft.atitle=Persistence+of+lysergic+acid+diethylamide+in+the+plasma+of+human+subjects&amp;rft.au=Aghajanian+GK%2C+Bing+OH&amp;rft.aulast=Aghajanian+GK%2C+Bing+OH&amp;rft.date=1964&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.maps.org%2Fw3pb%2Fnew%2F1964%2F1964_aghajanian_2224_1.pdf&amp;rft_id=info%3Apmid%2F14209776&amp;rft.jtitle=Clinical+Pharmacology+and+Therapeutics&amp;rft.pages=611-614&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.volume=5">
          <span style="display:none;">
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </li>
       <li id="cite_note-Papac-5">

       <li id="cite_note-16">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-16">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         Arthur Stoll and Albert Hofmann
         <a class="external text" href="http://www.erowid.org/archive/rhodium/chemistry/lsdpatent.html" rel="nofollow">
          LSD Patent
         </a>
         April 30, 1943 in Switzerland and March 23, 1948 in the United States.
        </span>
       </li>
       <li id="cite_note-17">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-17">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <span class="citation web">
          <a class="external text" href="http://www.rsc.org/chemistryworld/Issues/2006/January/LSD.asp" rel="nofollow">
           "LSD: cultural revolution and medical advances"
          </a>
          .
          <i>
           Royal Society of Chemistry
          </i>
          <span class="reference-accessdate">
           . Retrieved
           <span class="nowrap">
            September 27,
           </span>
           2007
          </span>
          .
         </span>
         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ALysergic+acid+diethylamide&amp;rft.atitle=LSD%3A+cultural+revolution+and+medical+advances&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.rsc.org%2Fchemistryworld%2FIssues%2F2006%2FJanuary%2FLSD.asp&amp;rft.jtitle=Royal+Society+of+Chemistry&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal">
          <span style="display:none;">
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </li>
       <li id="cite_note-18">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-18">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <span class="citation" id="CITEREFHarris2014">
          Harris, Sam (2014), "The spiritual uses of pharmacology",
          <a class="external text" href="http://books.google.com/books?id=SpJqBAAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA186" rel="nofollow">
           <i>
            Waking Up: A Guide to Spirituality Without Religion
           </i>
          </a>
          , Simon and Schuster, pp.186200,
          <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">
           ISBN
          </a>
          <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9781451636017" title="Special:BookSources/9781451636017">
           9781451636017
          </a>
          ,
          <q>
           I found psilocybin and LSD to be indispensable tools, and some of the most important hours of my life were spent under their influence... psychedelics... often reveal, in the span of a few hours, depths of awe and understanding that can otherwise elude us for a lifetime.
          </q>
         </span>
         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ALysergic+acid+diethylamide&amp;rft.atitle=The+spiritual+uses+of+pharmacology&amp;rft.aufirst=Sam&amp;rft.au=Harris%2C+Sam&amp;rft.aulast=Harris&amp;rft.btitle=Waking+Up%3A+A+Guide+to+Spirituality+Without+Religion&amp;rft.date=2014&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DSpJqBAAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPA186&amp;rft.isbn=9781451636017&amp;rft.pages=186-200&amp;rft.pub=Simon+and+Schuster&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook">
          <span style="display:none;">
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </li>
       <li id="cite_note-linton-langs-19">

        </span>

          </sup>
         </a>
         <a href="#cite_ref-henderson-glass_70-1">
          <sup>
           <i>
            <b>
             b
            </b>
           </i>
          </sup>
         </a>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <span class="citation book">
          Henderson, Leigh A.; Glass, William J. (1994).
          <i>
           LSD: Still with us after all these years
          </i>
          . San Francisco: Jossey-Bass.
          <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">

          </a>
          <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-7879-4379-0" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-7879-4379-0">
           978-0-7879-4379-0
          </a>
          .

          <sup>

         <span class="citation web">

          <a class="external text" href="http://web.archive.org/web/20070829023659/http://www.fas.org/irp/agency/doj/dea/product/lsd/lsd-5.htm" rel="nofollow">

          on August 29, 2007.
         </span>
         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ALysergic+acid+diethylamide&amp;rft.atitle=LSD+Manufacture+%E2%80%93+Illegal+LSD+Production&amp;rft.au=DEA&amp;rft.aulast=DEA&amp;rft.date=2007&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.fas.org%2Firp%2Fagency%2Fdoj%2Fdea%2Fproduct%2Flsd%2Flsd-5.htm&amp;rft.jtitle=LSD+in+the+United+States&amp;rft.pub=U.S.+Department+of+Justice+Drug+Enforcement+Administration&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal">
          <span style="display:none;">
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </li>

           ^

        </span>

          Krebs TS, Johansen P (March 8, 2012).
          <a class="external text" href="http://jop.sagepub.com/content/early/2012/03/08/0269881112439253.full.pdf+html" rel="nofollow">

          </a>

          </b>
          (7): 9941002.
          <a href="/wiki/Digital_object_identifier" title="Digital object identifier">

     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Further_reading">
       Further reading
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="refbegin columns references-column-width" style="-moz-column-width: 30em; -webkit-column-width: 30em; column-width: 30em;">
      <ul>
       <li>
        Marks, John.
        <i>
         The Search for the Manchurian Candidate: The CIA and Mind Control
        </i>
        (1979),
        <a class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn" href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0812907736">
         ISBN 0-8129-0773-6
        </a>
       </li>
       <li>
        Hofmann, Albert.
        <a class="external text" href="http://books.google.com/books?id=U6uhAAAACAAJ" rel="nofollow">
         <i>
          LSD My Problem Child: Reflections on Sacred Drugs, Mysticism and Science
         </i>
        </a>
        (1983)
        <a class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn" href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9780966001983">
         ISBN 978-0-9660019-8-3
        </a>
       </li>
       <li>
        Lee, Martin A. and Bruce Shlain.
        <i>
         Acid Dreams: The Complete Social History of LSD: The CIA, the Sixties, and Beyond
        </i>
        (1992)
        <a class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn" href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9780802130624">
         ISBN 978-0-8021-3062-4
        </a>
       </li>
       <li>
        Henderson, Leigh A. and William J. Glass.
        <i>
         LSD: Still With Us After All These Years: Based on the National Institute of Drug Abuse Studies on the Resurgence of Contemporary LSD Use
        </i>
        (1st edition 1994, 2nd edition 1998)
        <a class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn" href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9780787943790">
         ISBN 978-0-7879-4379-0
        </a>
       </li>
       <li>
        Stevens, Jay.
        <i>
         Storming Heaven: LSD And The American Dream
        </i>
        (1998)
        <a class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn" href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9780802135872">
         ISBN 978-0-8021-3587-2
        </a>
       </li>
       <li>
        Grof, Stanislav.
        <i>
         LSD Psychotherapy
        </i>
        . (April 10, 2001)
       </li>
       <li>
        de Rios, Marlene Dobkin and Oscar Janiger.
        <a class="external text" href="http://books.google.com/books?id=BSLGKvZpe8QC&amp;dq" rel="nofollow">
         <i>
          LSD, spirituality, and the creative process
         </i>
        </a>
        (2003, Inner Traditions)
        <a class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn" href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9780892819737">
         ISBN 978-0-89281-973-7
        </a>
         "An exploration of how LSD influences imagination and the creative process. Based on the results of one of the longest clinical studies of LSD that took place between 1954 and 1962, before LSD was illegal. Includes personal reports, artwork, and poetry from the original sessions as testimony of the impact of LSD on the creative process."
       </li>
       <li>
        Roberts, Andy.
        <i>
         Albion Dreaming: A Popular History of LSD in Britain
        </i>
        (2008), Marshall Cavendish, U.K,
        <a class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn" href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/1905736274">
         ISBN 1-905736-27-4
        </a>
       </li>
       <li>
        Bebergal, Peter,
        <a class="external text" href="http://thephoenix.com/Boston/News/62230-Will-Harvard-drop-acid-again/" rel="nofollow">
         "Will Harvard drop acid again? Psychedelic research returns to Crimsonland"
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/The_Phoenix_(newspaper)" title="The Phoenix (newspaper)">
         The Phoenix
        </a>
        (Boston), June 2, 2008
       </li>
       <li>
        <span class="citation journal">
         Passie T, Halpern JH, Stichtenoth DO, Emrich HM, Hintzen A (2008). "The pharmacology of lysergic acid diethylamide: a review".
         <i>
          CNS Neuroscience &amp; Therapeutics
         </i>
         <b>
          14
         </b>
         (4): 295314.
         <a href="/wiki/Digital_object_identifier" title="Digital object identifier">
          doi
         </a>
         :
         <a class="external text" href="//dx.doi.org/10.1111%2Fj.1755-5949.2008.00059.x" rel="nofollow">
          10.1111/j.1755-5949.2008.00059.x
         </a>
         .
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/PubMed_Identifier" title="PubMed Identifier">
          PMID
         </a>
         <a class="external text" href="//www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19040555" rel="nofollow">
          19040555
         </a>
         .
        </span>
        <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ALysergic+acid+diethylamide&amp;rft.atitle=The+pharmacology+of+lysergic+acid+diethylamide%3A+a+review&amp;rft.aulast=Passie+T%2C+Halpern+JH%2C+Stichtenoth+DO%2C+Emrich+HM%2C+Hintzen+A&amp;rft.au=Passie+T%2C+Halpern+JH%2C+Stichtenoth+DO%2C+Emrich+HM%2C+Hintzen+A&amp;rft.date=2008&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1111%2Fj.1755-5949.2008.00059.x&amp;rft_id=info%3Apmid%2F19040555&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.jtitle=CNS+Neuroscience+%26+Therapeutics&amp;rft.pages=295-314&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.volume=14">
         <span style="display:none;">
         </span>
        </span>
       </li>
       <li>
        <a class="external text" href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-10996838" rel="nofollow">
         BBC News: Pont-Saint-Esprit poisoning: Did the CIA spread LSD?
        </a>
        (2010)
       </li>
       <li>
        Dale Bewan.
        <i>
         Dropping Acid: A Beginner's Guide to the Responsible Use of LSD for Self-Discovery
        </i>
        (1st edition 2013)
        <a class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn" href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/1492318191">
         ISBN 1492318191
        </a>
       </li>

       <td class="mbox-text plainlist">
        Wikinews has related news:
        <i>
         <b>
          <a class="extiw" href="//en.wikinews.org/wiki/Drug_website_surveys_LSD_users_and_culture" title="wikinews:Drug website surveys LSD users and culture">
           Drug website surveys LSD users and culture
          </a>
         </b>
        </i>
       </td>
      </tr>
     </table>
     <ul>
      <li>
       <a class="external text" href="http://www.emcdda.europa.eu/publications/drug-profiles/lsd" rel="nofollow">
        Drug Profiles: LSD
       </a>
       European Monitoring Centre for Drugs and Drug Addiction
      </li>
      <li>
       <a class="external text" href="http://www.erowid.org/chemicals/lsd/lsd.shtml" rel="nofollow">
        LSD-25
       </a>
       at
       <a href="/wiki/Erowid" title="Erowid">
        Erowid
       </a>
      </li>
      <li>
       <a class="external text" href="http://leda.lycaeum.org/?ID=10" rel="nofollow">
        The Lycaeum Archive: LSD
       </a>
      </li>
      <li>
       <a class="external text" href="http://tihkal.info/read.php?domain=tk&amp;id=26" rel="nofollow">
        LSD entry in TiHKAL  info
       </a>
      </li>
      <li>
       <a class="external text" href="http://www.nida.nih.gov/infofacts/hallucinogens.html" rel="nofollow">
        InfoFacts  Hallucinogens
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/National_Institute_on_Drug_Abuse" title="National Institute on Drug Abuse">
        NIDA
       </a>
      </li>
      <li>
       <a class="external text" href="http://ahp.apps01.yorku.ca/?p=97" rel="nofollow">
        Scholarly bibliography on the histories of LSD use
       </a>
      </li>
      <li>
       <a class="external text" href="http://www.scientificamerican.com/article.cfm?id=return-of-a-problem-child" rel="nofollow">
        LSD Returns-For Psychotherapeutics (Scientific American Magazine article)
       </a>
      </li>
      <li>
       <a class="external text" href="http://druginfo.nlm.nih.gov/drugportal/dpdirect.jsp?name=Lysergic+acid+diethylamide" rel="nofollow">
        U.S. National Library of Medicine: Drug Information Portal  Lysergic acid diethylamide
       </a>
      </li>
      <li>
       <a class="external text" href="http://books.google.com/books?id=ASoDAAAAMBAJ&amp;pg=PA60" rel="nofollow">
        <i>
         My LSD Trip: a non-cop, non-hippie report of the unvarnished facts
        </i>
       </a>
       , by Robert Gannon,
       <a href="/wiki/Popular_Science" title="Popular Science">
        Popular Science
       </a>
       Magazine, December 1967.
      </li>
      <li>
       <a class="external text" href="http://www.maps.org/sys/w3pb.pl" rel="nofollow">
        WWW Psychedelic Bibliography
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Multidisciplinary_Association_for_Psychedelic_Studies" title="Multidisciplinary Association for Psychedelic Studies">
        MAPS
       </a>
        large database of scientific publications on LSD and other psychedelics, fulltext PDFs
      </li>
     </ul>
     <p>
      <b>
       Documentaries
      </b>
     </p>
     <ul>
      <li>
       <a class="external text" href="http://www.nfb.ca/film/hofmanns_potion" rel="nofollow">
        <i>
         Hofmann's Potion
        </i>
       </a>
       a documentary on the origins of LSD
      </li>
      <li>
       <a class="external text" href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hZdz0G4lG6k" rel="nofollow">
        Power &amp; Control LSD in The Sixties
       </a>
       on
       <a href="/wiki/YouTube" title="YouTube">
        YouTube
       </a>
       , documentary film directed by Aron Ranen, 2006
      </li>
      <li>
       <a class="external text" href="http://channel.nationalgeographic.com/series/explorer/4094/Overview" rel="nofollow">
        <i>
         Inside LSD
        </i>
       </a>
       National Geographic Channel, 2009
      </li>
     </ul>

                     JWH-018
                    </a>
                   </li>
                   <li>
                    <a href="/wiki/Tetrahydrocannabinol" title="Tetrahydrocannabinol">
                     THC
                    </a>
                    (
                    <a href="/wiki/Cannabis_(drug)" title="Cannabis (drug)">
                     Cannabis
                    </a>
                   </li>
                   <li>
                    <a href="/wiki/Hashish" title="Hashish">
                     Hashish
                    </a>
                   </li>
                   <li>
                    <a href="/wiki/Hash_oil" title="Hash oil">
                     Hash oil
                    </a>
                    )
                   </li>
                  </ul>
                 </div>
                </td>
               </tr>

                 <table class="nowraplinks navbox-subgroup" style="border-spacing:0">
                  <tr>
                   <td class="navbox-list navbox-even" colspan="2" style="width:100%;padding:0px">
                    <div style="padding:0em 0.25em">
                     <dl>
                      <dt>
                       <span style="font-weight:normal;">
                        <i>
                         Nonselective
                        </i>
                       </span>
                      </dt>
                      <dd>
                       <a href="/wiki/Benmoxin" title="Benmoxin">
                        Benmoxin

                   1A

                  <tr>
                   <td class="navbox-list navbox-odd" colspan="2" style="width:100%;padding:0px">
                    <div style="padding:0em 0.25em">
                     <ul>
                      <li>
                       <i>
                        Agonists:
                       </i>
                       <a href="/wiki/8-OH-DPAT" title="8-OH-DPAT">

                       </a>
                      </li>

                       <a href="/wiki/Adatanserin" title="Adatanserin">
                        Adatanserin
                       </a>
                      </li>
                      <li>
                       <a href="/wiki/Amphetamine" title="Amphetamine">
                        Amphetamine
                       </a>
                      </li>
                      <li>
                       <a href="/wiki/Antidepressant" title="Antidepressant">
                        Antidepressants
                       </a>
                       (e.g.,
                       <a href="/wiki/Etoperidone" title="Etoperidone">
                        etoperidone
                       </a>
                       ,
                       <a href="/wiki/Nefazodone" title="Nefazodone">

                   <td class="navbox-list navbox-odd" colspan="2" style="width:100%;padding:0px">
                    <div style="padding:0em 0.25em">
                     <ul>
                      <li>
                       <i>
                        Unknown/unsorted:
                       </i>
                       <a href="/wiki/Ergoline" title="Ergoline">
                        Ergolines
                       </a>
                       (e.g.,
                       <a href="/wiki/Dihydroergotamine" title="Dihydroergotamine">
                        dihydroergotamine
                       </a>
                       ,
                       <a href="/wiki/Ergometrine" title="Ergometrine">
                        ergometrine (ergonovine)
                       </a>
                       ,
                       <a href="/wiki/Nicergoline" title="Nicergoline">
                        nicergoline
                       </a>

                      </li>
                     </ul>

                       </a>
                       )
                      </li>
                     </ul>
                    </div>
                   </td>
                  </tr>

                    </a>
                    (
                    <a href="/wiki/Niacin" title="Niacin">
                     Niacin
                    </a>
                   </li>
                   <li>
                    <a href="/wiki/Nicotinamide" title="Nicotinamide">
                     Nicotinamide
                    </a>
                    
                    <a href="/wiki/Nicotinamide_adenine_dinucleotide_phosphate" title="Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate">
                     NADPH
                    </a>
                    )
                   </li>
                   <li>
                    <a href="/wiki/Vitamin_B6" title="Vitamin B6">
                     Vitamin B
                     <sub>
                      6
                     </sub>
                    </a>
                    (
                    <a href="/wiki/Pyridoxine" title="Pyridoxine">
                     Pyridoxine
                    </a>
                   </li>
                   <li>
                    <a href="/wiki/Pyridoxamine" title="Pyridoxamine">
                     Pyridoxamine
                    </a>
                   </li>
                   <li>
                    <a href="/wiki/Pyridoxal" title="Pyridoxal">
                     Pyridoxal
                    </a>
                    
                    <a href="/wiki/Pyridoxal_phosphate" title="Pyridoxal phosphate">
                     Pyridoxal phosphate
                    </a>
                    )
                   </li>
                   <li>
                    <a href="/wiki/Folic_acid" title="Folic acid">
                     Vitamin B
                     <sub>
                      9
                     </sub>
                    </a>
                    (
                    <a href="/wiki/Folic_acid" title="Folic acid">
                     Folic Acid
                    </a>
                    
                    <a href="/wiki/Tetrahydrofolic_acid" title="Tetrahydrofolic acid">
                     Tetrahydrofolic acid
                    </a>
                    )
                   </li>
                   <li>
                    <a href="/wiki/Vitamin_C" title="Vitamin C">
                     Vitamin C
                    </a>
                    (
                    <a href="/wiki/Ascorbic_acid" title="Ascorbic acid">
                     Ascorbic acid
                    </a>
                    )
                   </li>
                   <li>
                    <a href="/wiki/Zinc" title="Zinc">
                     Zinc
                    </a>
                    (Zn
                    <sup>
                     2+
                    </sup>
                    )
                   </li>
                  </ul>
                 </div>
                </td>
               </tr>

              </a>
             </i>
             (Hawaiian Baby Woodrose),

               </i>
               spp.
              </a>
             </i>
             (Morning Glory, Tlitliltzin, Badoh Negro),
